Set out at an early hour. our peroge and the Canoes passed over to the Lard side in order to avoid a bank which was rappidly falling in on the Stard. the red perogue contrary to my expectation or wish passed under this bank by means of her toe line where I expected to have seen her carried under every instant. I did not discover that she was about to make this attempt untill it was too late for the men to reembark
column4: and retreating is more dangerous than proceeding in such cases; they therefore continued their passage up this bank
column5: and much to my satisfaction arrived safe above it. this cost me some moments of uneasiness
column6: her cargo was of much importance to us in our present advanced situation--We proceeded on six miles and came too on the lower side of the entrance of the little Missouri on the Lard shore in a fine plain where we determined to spend the day for the purpose of celestial observation. we sent out 10 hunters to procure some fresh meat. at this place made the following observations.-The night proved so cloudy that I could make no further observations. George Drewyer shot a Beaver this morning
column7: which we found swiming in the river a small distance below the entrance of the little Missouri. the beaver being seen in the day
column8: is a proof that they have been but little hunted
column9: as they always keep themselves closly concealed during the day where they are so.--found a great quantity of small onions in the plain where we encamped; had some of them collected and cooked
column10: found them agreeable. the bulb grows single
column11: is of an oval form
column12: white
column13: and about the size of a small bullet; the leaf resembles that of the shive
column14: and the hunters returned this eying with one deer only. the country about the mouth of this river had been recently hunted by the Minetares
column15: and the little game which they had not killed and frightened away
column16: was so extreemly shy that the hunters could not get in shoot of them.The little Missouri disembogues on the S. side of the Missouri 1693 miles from the confluence of the latter with the Mississippi. it is 134 yards wide at it's mouth
column17: and sets in with a bould current but it's greatest debth is not more than 21/2 feet. it's navigation is extreemly difficult
column18: owing to it's rapidity
column19: shoals and sand bars. it may however be navigated with small canoes a considerable distance. this river passes through the Northern extremity of the black hills where it is very narrow and rapid and it's banks high an perpendicular. it takes it's rise in a broken country West of the Black hills with the waters of the yellow stone river
column20: and a considerable distance S. W. of the point at which it passes the black hills. the country through which it passes is generally broken and the highlands possess but little timber. there is some timber in it's bottom lands
column21: which consists of Cottonwood red Elm
column22: with a small proportion of small Ash and box alder. the under brush is willow
column23: red wood
column24: (sometimes called red or swamp willow-) the red burry
column25: and Choke cherry the country is extreamly broken about the mouth of this river
column26: and as far up on both sides
column27: as we could observe it from the tops of some elivated hills
column28: which stand betwen these two rivers
column29: about 3 miles from their junction. the soil appears fertile and deep
column30: it consists generally of a dark rich loam intermixed with a small proportion of fine sand. this river in it's course passed near the N. W. side of the turtle mountain
column31: which is said to be no more than 4 or 5 leagues distant from it's entrance in a straight direction
column32: a little to the S. of West.--this mountain and the knife river have therefore been laid down too far S. W. the colour of the water
column33: the bed of the river
column34: and it's appearance in every respect
column35: resembles the Missouri; I am therefore induced to believe that the texture of the soil of the country in which it takes it's rise
column36: and that through which it passes
column37: is similar to the country through which the Missouri passes after leaving the woody country
column38: or such as we are now in.--on the side of a hill not distant from our camp I found some of the dwarf cedar of which I preserved a specimen (See No. 2). this plant spreads it's limbs alonge the surface of the earth
column39: where they are sometimes covered
column40: and always put forth a number of roots on the under side
column41: while on the upper there are a great number of small shoots which with their leaves seldom rise higher than 6 or eight inches. they grow so close as perfectly to conceal the eath. it is an evergreen; the leaf is much more delicate than the common Cedar
column42: and it's taste and smell the same. I have often thought that this plant would make very handsome edgings to the borders and walks of a garden; it is quite as handsom as box
column43: and would be much more easily propegated.--the appearance of the glauber salts and Carbonated wood still continue. [Clark
column44: April 12
column45: 1805] 12th April Friday 1805 a fine morning Set out verry early
column46: the murcery Stood 56° above 0. proceeded on to the mouth of the Little Missouri river and formed a Camp in a butifull elivated plain on the lower Side for the purpose of takeing Some observations to fix the Latitude & Longitude of this river. this river falls in on the L. Side and is 134 yards wide and 2 feet 6 Inches deep at the mouth
column47: it takes its rise in the N W extremity of the black mountains
column48: and through a broken countrey in its whole course washing the N W base of the Turtle Mountain which is Situated about 6 Leagues S W of its mouth
column49: one of our men Baptiest who came down this river in a canoe informs me that it is not navagable
column50: he was 45 days descending.

column1: I walked out on the lower Side of this river and found the countrey hilley the Soil composed of black mole & a Small perportion of Sand containing great quantity of Small peable Some limestone, black flint, & Sand Stone I killed a Hare Changeing its Colour Some parts retaining its long white fur & other parts assumeing the Short grey, I Saw the Magpie in pars, flocks of Grouse, the old field lark & Crows, & observed the leaf of the wild Chery half grown, many flowers are to be seen in the plains, remains of Minetarra & Ossinneboin hunting Camps are to be Seen on each Side of the two MissourisThe wind blew verry hard from the S. all the after part of the day, at 3 oClock P M. it became violent & flowey accompanied with thunder and a little rain. We examined our canoes &c found Several mice which had already commenced cutting our bags of corn & parched meal, the water of the little Missouri is of the Same texture Colour & quallity of that of the Big Missouri the after part of the day so Cloudy that we lost the evening observation. [Lewis, April 13, 1805] Saturday April 13th Being disappointed in my observations of yesterday for Longitude, I was unwilling to remain at the entrance of the river another day for that purpose, and therefore determined to set out early this morning; which we did accordingly; the wind was in our favour after 9 A.M. and continued favourable untill three 3 P.M. we therefore hoisted both the sails in the White Perogue, consisting of a small squar sail, and spritsail, which carried her at a pretty good gate, untill about 2 in the afternoon when a suddon squall of wind struck us and turned the perogue so much on the side as to allarm Sharbono who was steering at the time, in this state of alarm he threw the perogue with her side to the wind, when the spritsail gibing was as near overseting the perogue as it was possible to have missed. the wind however abating for an instant I ordered Drewyer to the helm and the sails to be taken in, which was instant executed and the perogue being steered before the wind was agin placed in a state of security. this accedent was very near costing us dearly. beleiving this vessell to be the most steady and safe, we had embarked on board of it our instruments, Papers, medicine and the most valuable part of the merchandize which we had still in reserve as presents for the Indians. we had also embarked on board ourselves, with three men who could not swim and the squaw with the young child, all of whom, had the perogue overset, would most probably have perished, as the waves were high, and the perogue upwards of 200 yards from the nearest shore; however we fortunately escaped and pursued our journey under the square sail, which shortly after the accident I directed to be again hoisted. our party caught three beaver last evening; and the French hunters 7. as there was much appearance of beaver just above the entrance of the little Missouri these hunters concluded to remain some days; we therefore left them without the expectation of seeing them again.--just above the entrance of the Little Missouri the great Missouri is upwards of a mile in width, tho immediately at the entrance of the former it is not more than 200 yards wide and so shallow that the canoes passed it with seting poles. at the distance of nine miles passed the mouth of a creek on the Stard. side which we called onion creek from the quantity of wild onions which grow in the plains on it's borders. Capt. Clark who was on shore informed me that this creek was 16 yards wide a mile & a half above it's entrance, discharges more water than creeks of it's size usually do in this open country, and that there was not a stick of timber of any discription to be seen on it's borders, or the level plain country through which it passes. at the distance of 10 miles further we passed the mouth of a large creek; discharging itself in the center of a deep bend. of this creek and the neighbouring country, Capt Clark who was on shore gave me the following discription "This creek I took to be a small river from it's size, and the quantity of water which it discharged. I ascended it 11/2 miles, and found it the discharge of a pond or small lake, which had the appearance of having formerly been the bed of the Missouri. several small streems discharge themselves into this lake. the country on both sides consists of beautifull level and elivated plains; asscending as they recede from the Missouri; there were a great number of Swan and gees in this lake and near it's borders I saw the remains of 43 temperary Indian lodges, which I presume were those of the Assinniboins who are now in the neighbourhood of the British establishments on the Assinniboin river-" This lake and it's discharge we call Boos Egg from the circumstance of Capt Clark shooting a goose while on her nest in the top of a lofty cotton wood tree, from which we afterwards took one egg. the wild gees frequently build their nests in this manner, at least we have already found several in trees, nor have we as yet seen any on the ground, or sand bars where I had supposed from previous information that they most commonly deposited their eggs.- saw some Bufhaloe and Elk at a distance today but killed none of them. we found a number of carcases of the Buffaloe lying along shore, which had been drowned by falling through the ice in winter and lodged on shore by the high water when the river broke up about the first of this month. we saw also many tracks of the white bear of enormous size, along the river shore and about the carcases of the Buffaloe, on which I presume they feed. we have not as yet seen one of these anamals, tho their tracks are so abundant and recent. the men as well as ourselves are anxious to meet with some of these bear. the Indians give a very formidable account of the strengh and ferocity of this anamal, which they never dare to attack but in parties of six eight or ten persons; and are even then frequently defeated with the loss of one or more of their party. the savages attack this anamal with their bows and arrows and the indifferent guns with which the traders furnish them, with these they shoot with such uncertainty and at so short a distance, that they frequently mis their aim & fall a sacrefice to the bear. two Minetaries were killed during the last winter in an attack on a white bear. this anamall is said more frequently to attack a man on meeting with him, than to flee from him. When the Indians are about to go in quest of the white bear, previous to their departure, they paint themselves and perform all those superstitious rights commonly observed when they are about to make war uppon a neighbouring nation. Oserved more bald eagles on this part of the Missouri than we have previously seen saw the small hawk, frequently called the sparrow hawk, which is common to most parts of the U States. great quantities of gees are seen feeding in the praries. saw a large flock of white brant or gees with black wings pass up the river; there were a number of gray brant with them; from their flight I presume they proceed much further still to the N. W.--we have never been enabled yet to shoot one of these birds, and cannot therefore determine whether the gray brant found with the white are their brude of the last year or whether they are the same with the grey brant common to the Mississippi and lower part of the Missouri.--we killed 2 Antelopes today which we found swiming from the S. to the N. side of the river; they were very poor.--We encamped this evening on the Stard. shore in a beautiful) plain, elivated about 30 feet above the river.

column3: 1805] 13th of April Satturday 1805 Set out this morning at 6 oClock
column4: the Missouri above the mouth of Little Missouri widens to nearly a mile containing a number of Sand bars this width &c. of the River Continues Generally as high as the Rochejhone River.Cought 3 beaver this morning
column5: at 9 miles passd. the mouth of a Creek on the S. S. on the banks of which there is an imence quantity of wild onions or garlick
column6: I was up this Creek 1/2 a m. and could not See one Stick of timber of any kind on its borders
column7: this creek is 16 yds wide 1/2 a mile up it and discharges more water than is common for Creeks of its Size. at about 10 miles higher we pass a Creek about 30 yards wide in a deep bend to the N W. This creek I took to be a Small river from its Size & the quantity of water which it discharged
column8: I ascended it 11/2 mes and found it the discharge of a pond or Small Lake which has appearance of haveing been once the bead of the river
column9: Some Small Streams discharge themselves into this Lake. the Countery on both Side is butifull elevated plains assending in Some parts to a great distance near the aforesaid Lake (which we call Goose egg L from a Circumstance of my Shooting a goose on her neast on Some Sticks in the top of a high Cotton wood tree in which there was one egg) We Saw 8 buffalow at a distance
column10: We also Saw Several herds of Elk at a distance which were verry wild
column11: I Saw near the Lake the remains of 43 lodges
column12: which has latterly been abandond I Suppose them to have been Ossinniboins and now near the british establishments on the Ossinniboin River tradeing. we camped on the S. S. in a butifull Plain. I observe more bald Eagles on this part of the Missouri than usial also a Small Hawk Killed 2 Antelopes in the river to day emence numbers of Geese to be seen pared &c. a Gange of brant pass one half of the gange white with black wings or the large feathers of the 1 s & 2d joint the remds. of the comn. color. a voice much like that of a goos & finer &c. [Lewis
column13: April 14
column14: 1805] Sunday April 14th 1805. One of the hunters saw an Otter last evening and shot at it
column15: but missed it. a dog came to us this morning
column16: which we supposed to have been lost by the Indians who were recently encamped near the lake that we passed yesterday. the mineral appearances of salts
column17: coal and sulpher
column18: together with birnt hills & pumicestone still continue.--while we remained at the entrance of the little Missouri
column19: we saw several pieces of pumice stone floating down that stream
column20: a considerable quanty of which had lodged against a point of drift wood a little above it's entrance. Capt. Clark walked on shore this morning
column21: and on his return informed me that he had passed through the timbered bottoms on the N. side of the river
column22: and had extended his walk several miles back on the hills; in the bottom lands he had met with several uninhabited Indian lodges built with the boughs of the Elm
column23: and in the plains he met with the remains of two large encampments of a recent date
column24: which from the appearance of some hoops of small kegs
column25: seen near them we concluded that they must have been the camps of the Assinniboins
column26: as no other nation who visit this part of the missouri ever indulge themselves with spirituous liquor. of this article the Assinniboins are pationately fond
column27: and we are informed that it forms their principal inducement to furnish the British establishments on the Assinniboin river with the dryed and pounded meat and grease which they do. they also supply those establishments with a small quantity of fur
column28: consisting principally of the large and small wolves and the small fox skins. these they barter for small kegs of ruin which they generally transport to their camps at a distance from the establishments
column29: where they revel with their friends and relations as long as they possess the means of intoxication
column30: their women and children are equally indulged on those occations and are all seen drunk together. so far is a state of intoxication from being a cause of reproach among them
column31: that with the men
column32: it is a matter of exultation that their skill and industry as hunters has enabled them to get drunk frequently. in their customs
column33: habits
column34: and dispositions these people very much resemble the Siouxs from whom they have descended. The principal inducement with the British fur companies
column35: for continuing their establishments on the Assinniboin river
column36: is the Buffaloe meat and grease they procure from the Assinniboins
column37: and Christanoes
column38: by means of which
column39: they are enabled to supply provision to their engages on their return from rainy Lake to the English river and the Athabaskey country where they winter; without such resource those voyagers would frequently be straitened for provision
column40: as the country through which they pass is but scantily supplyed with game
column41: and the rappidity with which they are compelled to travel in order to reach their winter stations
column42: would leave therm but little leasure to surch for food while on their voyage.The Assinniboins have so recently left this neighbourhood
column43: that the game is scarce and very shy. the river continues wide
column44: and not more rapid than the Ohio in an averge state of it's current. the bottoms are wide and low
column45: the moister parts containing some timber; the upland is extreemly broken
column46: chonsisting of high gaulded nobs as far as the eye can reach on ether side
column47: and entirely destitute of timber. on these hills many aromatic herbs are seen; resembling in taste
column48: smel and appearance
column49: the sage
column50: hysop
column51: wormwood
column52: southernwood and two other herbs which are strangers to me; the one resembling the camphor in taste and smell
column53: rising to the hight of 2 or 3 feet; the other about the same size
column54: has a long
column55: narrow
column56: smooth
column57: soft leaf of an agreeable smel and flavor; of this last the Atelope is very fond; they feed on it
column58: and perfume the hair of their foreheads and necks with it by rubing against it. the dwarf cedar and juniper is also found in great abundance on the sides of these hills. where the land is level
column59: it is uniformly fertile consisting of a dark loam intermixed with a proportion of fine sand. it is generally covered with a short grass resembling very much the blue grass.--the miniral appearances still continue; considerable quantities of bitumenous water
column60: about the colour of strong lye trickles down the sides of the hills; this water partakes of the taste of glauber salts and slightly of allumn.--while the party halted to take dinner today Capt Clark killed a buffaloe bull; it was meagre
column61: and we therefore took the marrow bones and a small proportion of the meat only. near the place we dined on the Lard. side
column62: there was a large village of burrowing squirrels. I have remarked that these anamals generally celect a South Easterly exposure for their residence
column63: tho they are sometimes found in the level plains.--passed an Island
column64: above which two small creeks fall in on Lard side; the upper creek largest
column65: which we called Sharbono's Creek after our interpreter who encamped several weeks on it with a hunting party of Indians. this was the highest point to which any whiteman had ever ascended; except two Frenchmen who having lost their way had straggled a few miles further
column66: tho to what place precisely I could not learn.--I walked on shore above this creek and killed an Elk
column67: which was so poor that it was unfit for uce; I therefore left it
column68: and joined the party at their encampment on the Stard shore a little after dark. on my arrival Capt Clark informed me that he had seen two white bear pass over the hills shortly after I fired
column69: and that they appeared to run nearly from the place where I shot. the lard. shore on which I walked was very broken
column70: and the hills in many places had the appearance of having sliped down in masses of several acres of land in surface.--we saw many gees feeding on the tender grass in the praries and several of their nests in the trees; we have not in a single instance found the nest of this bird on or near the ground. we saw a number of Magpies their nests and eggs. their nests are built in trees and composed of small sticks leaves and grass
column71: open at top
column72: and much in the stile of the large blackbird comm to the U States. the egg is of a bluish brown colour
column73: freckled with redish brown spots. one of the party killed a large hooting owl. I observed no difference between this burd and those of the same family common to the U States
column74: except that this appeared to be more booted and more thickly clad with feathers.-

column1: [Clark, April 14, 1805] 14th of April Sunday 1805. a fine morning, a dog came to us this morning we Suppose him to be left by the Inds. who had their camps near the Lake we passd. yesterday not long Sence, I observed Several Single Lodges built of Stiks of cotten timber in different parts of the bottoms. in my walk of this day which was through the wooded bottoms and on the hills for several miles back from the river on the S. S. I Saw the remains of two Indian incampments with wide beeten tracks leading to them. those were no doubt the Camps of the Ossinnaboin Indians (a Strong evidence is hoops of Small Kegs were found in the incampments) no other nation on the river above the Sioux make use of Spiritious licquer, the Ossinniboins is said to be pasionately fond of Licquer, and is the principal inducement to their putting themselves to the trouble of Catching the fiew wolves and foxes which they furnish, and recive their liquor always in small Kegs. The Ossinniboins make use of the Same kind of Lodges which the Sioux and other Indians on this river make use of--Those lodges or tents are made of a number of dressed buffalow Skins Sowed together with Sinues & deckerated with the tales, & Porcupine quils, when open it forms a half circle with a part about 4 Inches wide projecting about 8 or 9 Inches from the center of the Streight Side for the purpose of attaching it to a pole to it the hight they wish to raise the tent, when they errect this tent four poles of equal length are tied near one end, those poles are elevated and 8 10 or 12 other poles are anexed forming a Circle at the ground and lodging in the forks of the four attached poles, the tents are then raised, by attach the projecting part to a pole and incumpassing the poles with the tent by bringing the two ends together and attached with a Cord, or laied as high as is necessary, leaveing the lower part open for about 4 feet for to pass in & out, and the top is generally left open to admit the Smoke to pass--The Borders of the river has been So much hunted by those Indians who must have left it about 8 or 10 days past and I prosume are now in the neighbourhood of British establishments on the Osinniboin; the game is Scerce and verry wild. The River Continues wide and the current jentle not more rapid than the Current of the Ohio in middle State--The bottoms are wide and low and the moist parts of them Contain Som wood such as cotton Elm & Small ash, willow rose bushes &c. &c. &. next to the hills Great quantity of wild Isoop, the hills are high broken in every direction, and the mineral appearance of Salts Continue to appear in a greater perportion, also Sulpher, Coal & bitumous water in a Smaller quantity, I have observed but five burnt hills, about the little Missouri, and I have not Seen any pumey stone above that River I Saw Buffalow on the L. S. Crossed and dureing the time of dinner killed a Bull, which was pore, we made use of the best of it, I Saw a village of Burrowing dogs on the L. S. passed a Island above which two Small Creeks falls in on the L. S. the upper of which is the largest and we call Shabonas Creek after our interpreter who incamped several weeks on this Creek and is the highest point on the Missouri to which a white man has been previous to this time. Capt. Lewis walked out above this creek and killed an Elk which he found So meager that it was not fit for use, and joined the boat at Dusk at our Camp on the S. S. opposit a high hill Several parts of which had Sliped down. on the Side of those hills we Saw two white bear running from the report of Capt. Lewis Shot, those animals assended those Steep hills with Supprising ease & verlocity. they were too far to discover their prosise Colour & Size--Saw Several gees nests on trees, also the nests & egs of the Magpies, a large grey owl killed, booted & with ears &c. [Lewis, April 15, 1805] Monday April 15th 1805. Set out at an early hour this morning. I walked on shore, and Capt. Clark continued with the party it being an invariable rule with us not to be both absent from our vessels at the same time. I passed through the bottoms of the river on the Stard. side. they were partially covered with timber & were extensive, level and beatifull. in my walk which was about 6 miles I passed a small rivulet of clear water making down from the hills, which on tasting, I discovered to be in a small degree brackish. it possessed less of the glauber salt, or alumn, than those little streams from the hills usually do.--in a little pond of water fromed by this rivulet where it entered the bottom, I heard the frogs crying for the first time this season; their note was the same with that of the small frogs which are common to the lagoons and swamps of the U States.--I saw great quantities of gees feeding in the bottoms, of which I shot one. saw some deer and Elk, but they were remarkably shy. I also met with great numbers of Grouse or prarie hens as they are called by the English traders of the N. W. these birds appeared to be mating; the note of the male is kuck, kuck, kuck, coo, coo, coo. the first part of the note both male and female use when flying. the male also dubbs something like the pheasant, but by no means as loud. after breakfast Capt. Clark walked on the Std. shore, and on his return in the evening gave me the following account of his ramble. "I ascended to the high country, about 9 miles distant from the Missouri. the country consists of beatifull, level and fertile plains, destitute of timber I saw many little dranes, which took their rise in the river hills, from whence as far as I could see they run to the N. E." these streams we suppose to be the waters of Mous river a branch of the Assinniboin which the Indians informed us approaches the Missouri very nearly, about this point. "I passed," continued he, "a Creek about 20 yards wide," which falls into the Missouri; the bottoms of this creek are wide level and extreemly fertile, but almost entirely destitute of timber. the water of this creek as well as all those creeks and rivulets which we have passed since we left Fort Mandan was so strongly impregnated with salts and other miniral substances that I was incapable of drinking it. I saw the remains of several camps of the Assinniboins; near one of which, in a small ravene, there was a park which they had formed of timber and brush, for the purpose of taking the Cabrie or Antelope. it was constructed in the following manner. a strong pound was first made of timbers, on one side of which there was a small apparture, sufficiently large to admit an Antelope; from each side of this apparture, a curtain was extended to a considerable distance, widening as they receded from the pound.--we passed a rock this evening standing in the middle of the river, and the bed of the river was formed principally of gravel. we encamped this evening on a sand point on Lard. side. a little above our encampment the river was confined to a channel of 80 yards in width.-

column3: 1805] 17th of April Wednesday 1805 a fine morning wind from the S E. Genly to day handsom high extencive rich Plains on each Side
column4: the mineral appearances continue with greater appearances of Coal
column5: much greater appearance of the hills haveing been burnt
column6: more Pumice Stone & Lava washed down to the bottoms and some Pumice Stone floating in the river
column7: I walked on the S. S. Saw great numbs. of Buffalow feeding in the Plains at a distance Capt. Lewis killed 2 Buffalow buls which was near the water at the time of dineing
column8: they were So pore as to be unfit for use. I Saw Several Small parties of antelopes large herds of Elk
column9: Some white wolves
column10: and in a pond (formed on the S. S. by the Missouries Changeing its bead) I Saw Swan Gees & different kinds of Ducks in great numbers also a Beaver house. Passed a Small Creek on the S. S. & Several runs of water on each Side
column11: Saw the remains of Indian camps in every point of timbered land on the S. S. in the evining a thunder gust passed from the S W
column12: without rain
column13: about Sunset Saw Some fresh Indians track and four rafts on the shore S. S. Those I prosume were Ossinniboins who had been on a war party against the Rockey Mountain Indians--Saw a Curlow
column14: Some verry large beaver taken this morning. those animals are made use of as food and preferred by the party to any other at this Season [Lewis
column15: April 18
column16: 1805] Thursday April 18th 1805. A fine morning
column17: set out at an early hour. one Beaver caught this morning by two traps
column18: having a foot in each; the traps belonged to different individuals
column19: between whom
column20: a contest ensued
column21: which would have terminated
column22: most probably
column23: in a serious rencounter had not our timely arrival at the place prevented it. after breakfast this morning
column24: Capt. Clark walked on Stad. shore
column25: while the party were assending by means of their toe lines
column26: I walked with them on the bank; found a species of pea bearing a yellow flower
column27: and now in blume; it seldom rises more than 6 inches high
column28: the leaf & stalk resembles that of the common gardin pea
column29: the root is pirenial. (See specimen of vegitables No. 3.) I also saw several parsels of buffaloe's hair hanging on the rose bushes
column30: which had been bleached by exposure to the weather and became perfectly white. it every appearance of the wool of the sheep
column31: tho much finer and more silkey and soft. I am confident that an excellent cloth may be made of the wool of the Buffaloe. the Buffaloe I killed yesterday had cast his long hare
column32: and the poll which remained was very thick
column33: fine
column34: and about 2 inches in length. I think this anamal would have furnished about five pounds of wool. we were detained today from one to five P.M. in consequence of the wind which blew so violently from N. that it was with difficulty we could keep the canoes from filling with water altho they were along shore; I had them secured by placing the perogues on the out side of them in such manner as to break the waves off them. at 5 we proceed
column35: and shortly after met with Capt. Clark
column36: who had killed an Elk and a deer and was wating our arrival. we took the meat on board and continued our march untill nearly dark when we came too on the Stard side under a boald welltimbered bank which sheltered us from the wind which had abated but not yet ceased. here we encamped
column37: it being the extremity of the last course of this day.- [Clark
column38: April 18
column39: 1805] 18th of April Thursday 1805 Set out at an early hour one Beaver & a Musrat Cought this morning
column40: the beaver cought in two traps
column41: which like to have brought about a missunderstanding between two of the party &c. after brackfast I assended a hill and observed that the river made a great bend to the South
column42: I concluded to walk thro the point about 2 miles and take Shabono
column43: with me
column44: he had taken a dost of Salts &c. his Squar followed on with his child
column45: when I Struck the next bend of the river could See nothing of the Party
column46: left this man & his wife & Child on the river bank and went out to hunt
column47: Killed a young Buck Elk
column48: & a Deer
column49: the Elk was tolerable meat
column50: the Deer verry pore
column51: Butcherd the meat and Continued untill near Sunset before Capt Lewis and the party Came up
column52: they were detained by the wind
column53: which rose Soon after I left the boat from the N W. & blew verry hard untill verry late in the evening. we Camped on the S. S. in an excellent harbor
column54: Soon after We came too
column55: two men went up the river to Set their beaver traps they met with a Bear and being without their arms thought prodent to return &c. the wild Cheries are in bloom
column56: Great appearance of Burnt hills Pumice Stone &c. the Coal & Salt appearance Continued
column57: the water in the Small runs much better than below
column58: --Saw Several old Indian Camps
column59: the game
column60: Such as Buffalow Elk
column61: antelopes & Deer verry plenty [Lewis
column62: April 19
column63: 1805] Friday April 19th 1805. The wind blew So hard this morning from N. W. that we dared not to venture our canoes on the river.--Observed considerable quantities of dwarf Juniper on the hillsides (see specimen No. 4) it seldom rises higher then 3 feet.--the wind detained us through the couse of this day
column64: tho we were fortunate in having placed ourselves in a safe harbour. the party killed one Elk and a beaver today. The beaver of this part of the Missouri are larger
column65: fatter
column66: more abundant and better clad with fur than those of any other part of the country that I have yet seen; I have remarked also that their fur is much darker.

column3: 1805] 21st of April Sunday 1805 Set out early the wind gentle & from the N. W. the river being verry Crooked
column4: I concluded to walk through the point
column5: the Countrey on either Side is verry Similar to that we have passed
column6: Saw an emence number of Elk & Buffalow
column7: also Deer Antelopes Geese Ducks & a fiew Swan
column8: the Buffalow is about Calveing I killed a Buffalow & 4 Deer in my walk to day
column9: the party killed 2 deer 2 beaver & 4 Buffalow Calves
column10: which was verry good veele. I Saw old Camps of Indians on the L. Side
column11: we passed 1 large & 2 Small Creeks on the L. Side neither of them discharge any water into the river
column12: in the evening the wind became verry hard a head
column13: we made Camp at a late hour which was on the L. Side a little above the mouth of White Earth River which falls in on the Stad Side and is 60 yds. wide
column14: several Mes. up [Lewis
column15: April 22
column16: 1805] Monday April 22cd 1805. Set out at an early hour this morning; proceeded pretty well untill breakfat
column17: when the wind became so hard a head that we proceeded with difficulty even with the assistance of our toe lines. the party halted and Cpt. Clark and myself walked to the white earth river which approaches the Missouri very near at this place
column18: being about 4 miles above it's entrance. we found that it contained more water than streams of it's size generally do at this season. the water is much clearer than that of the Missouri. the banks of the river are steep and not more than ten or twelve feet high; the bed seems to be composed of mud altogether. the salts which have been before mentioned as common on the Missouri
column19: appears in great quantities along the banks of this river
column20: which are in many places so thickly covered with it that they appear perfectly white. perhaps it has been from this white appearance of it's banks that the river has derived it's name. this river is said to be navigable nearly to it's source
column21: which is at no great distance from the Saskashawan
column22: and I think from it's size the direction which it seems to take
column23: and the latitude of it's mouth
column24: that there is very good ground to believe that it extends as far North as latitude 50°.--this stream passes through an open country generally.--the broken hills of the Missouri about this place exhibit large irregular and broken masses of rocks and stones; some of which tho 200 feet above the level of the water seem at some former period to have felt it's influence
column25: fo they appear smoth as if woarn by the agetation of the water. this collection consists of white & grey gannite
column26: a brittle black rock
column27: flint
column28: limestone
column29: freestone
column30: some small specimens of an excellent pebble and occasionally broken stratas of a stone which appears to be petrefyed wood
column31: it is of a black colour
column32: and makes excellent whetstones. Coal or carbonated wood pumice stone lava and other mineral apearances still continue. the coal appears to be of better quality; I exposed a specimen of it to the fire and found that it birnt tolerably well
column33: it afforded but little flame or smoke
column34: but produced a hot and lasting fire.--I asscended to the top of the cutt bluff this morning
column35: from whence I had a most delightfull view of the country
column36: the whole of which except the vally formed by the Missouri is void of timber or underbrush
column37: exposing to the first glance of the spectator immence herds of Buffaloe
column38: Elk
column39: deer
column40: & Antelopes feeding in one common and boundless pasture. we saw a number of bever feeding on the bark of the trees alonge the verge of the river
column41: several of which we shot
column42: found them large and fat. walking on shore this evening I met with a buffaloe calf which attatched itself to me and continued to follow close at my heels untill I embarked and left it. it appeared allarmed at my dog which was probably the cause of it's so readily attatching itself to me. Capt Clark informed me that he saw a large drove of buffaloe pursued by wolves today
column43: that they at length caught a calf which was unable to keep up with the herd. the cows only defend their young so long as they are able to keep up with the herd
column44: and seldom return any distance in surch of them.- [Clark
column45: April 22
column46: 1805] 22nd of April Monday 1805 a verry cold morning Some frost
column47: we Set out at an early hour and proceeded on verry well untill brackfast at which time the wind began to blow verry hard ahead
column48: and Continued hard all day we proceeded on with much dificuelty with the assistance of the toe Ropes. Capt. Lewis & my Self walked to the ____ River which is near the Missouri four miles above its mouth
column49: this river is 60 yards wide and contains a greater perportion of water at this time than is Common for Rivers of its Size it appears navagable as fur as any of the party was
column50: and I am told to near its Source in morrasses in the open Plains
column51: it passes (as far as we can See which is 6 or 7 Leagus) thro a butifull extinsive vallie
column52: rich & fertile and at this time Covered with Buffalow
column53: Elk & antelopes
column54: which may be Seen also in any other direction in this quarter--this river must take its rise at no great distance Easte of the Saskashawan
column55: and no doubt as far N. as Latd. 50°Some of the high plains or the broken Revien of the river contains great quantity of Pebble Stones of various Sizes
column56: The Stratum of Coal is much richer than below
column57: the appearances of Mineral & burnt hills Still continue the river riseing a little
column58: Saw an emence number of beaver feeding on the waters edge & Swiming Killed Several
column59: Capt. Lewis assended a hill from the top of which he had a most inchanting prospect of the Countrey around & the meanderings of the two rivers
column60: which is remarkable Crooked--a buffalow calf which was on the Shore alone followed Cap Lewis Some distance
column61: --I observed a large drove of buffalow prosued by wolves the wolves cought one of their Calves in my view
column62: those animals defend their young as long as they Can keep up with the drove [Lewis
column63: April 23
column64: 1805] Tuesday April 23rd Set out at an early hour this morning. about nine A.M. the wind arose
column65: and shortly after became so violent that we were unabled to proceed
column66: in short it was with much difficulty and some risk that I was enabled to get the canoes and perogues into a place of tolerable safety
column67: there being no timber on either side of the river at this place. some of the canoes shiped water
column68: and wet several parsels of their lading
column69: which I directed to be opened and aired we remained untill five in the evening when the wind abating in some measure
column70: we reloaded
column71: and proceeded. shortly after we were joined by Capt. Clark who had walked on shore this morning
column72: and passing through the bottom lands had fallen on the river some miles above
column73: and concluding that the wind had detained us
column74: came down the river in surch of us. he had killed three blacktaled
column75: or mule deer
column76: and a buffaloe Calf
column77: in the course of his ramble. these hard winds
column78: being so frequently repeated
column79: become a serious source of detention to us.--incamped on the Stard. side.-

column3: 1805] 23rd of April 1805 a cold morning at about 9 oClock the wind as usial rose from the N W and continued to blow verry hard untill late in the evening I walked on Shore after brackfast in my walk on the S side passed through extensive bottoms of timber intersperced with glades & low open plains
column4: I killed 3 mule or black tail Deer
column5: which was in tolerable order
column6: Saw Several others
column7: I also killed a Buffalow Calf which was verry fine
column8: I Struck the river above the Perogus which had Come too in a bend to the L. S. to Shelter from the wind which had become violently hard
column9: I joined Capt Lewis in the evening & after the winds falling which was late in the evening we proceeded on & encamped on the S. S. The winds of this Countrey which blow with Some violence almost every day
column10: has become a Serious obstruction in our progression onward
column11: as we Cant move when the wind is high without great risque
column12: and if there was no risque the winds is generally a head and often too violent to proceed [Lewis
column13: April 24
column14: 1805] Wednesday April 24th The wind blew so hard during the whole of this day
column15: that we were unable to move. notwithstanding that we were sheltered by high timber from the effects of the wind
column16: such was it's violence that it caused the waves to rise in such manner as to wet many articles in the small canoes before they could be unloaded. we sent out some hunters who killed 4 deer & 2 Elk
column17: and caught some young wolves of the small kind.--Soar eyes is a common complaint among the party. I believe it origenates from the immence quantities of sand which is driven by the wind from the sandbars of the river in such clouds that you are unable to discover the opposite bank of the river in many instances. the particles of this sand are so fine and light that they are easily supported by the air
column18: and are carried by the wind for many miles
column19: and at a distance exhibiting every appearance of a collumn of thick smoke. so penitrating is this sand that we cannot keep any article free from it; in short we are compelled to eat
column20: drink
column21: and breath it very freely. my pocket watch
column22: is out of order
column23: she will run only a few minutes without stoping. I can discover no radical defect in her works
column24: and must therefore attribute it to the sand
column25: with which
column26: she seems plentifully charged
column27: notwithstanding her cases are double and tight. [Clark
column28: April 24
column29: 1805] 24th of April Wednesday 1805 The wind rose last night and continued blowing from the N. & N W. and Sometimes with great violence
column30: untill 7 oClock P. M
column31: Several articles wet in the Perogues by their takeing water &c. as the wind was a head we could not move today Sent out hunters
column32: they killed 4 Deer 2 Elk & cought Some young wolves of the Small kind
column33: The party complain much of the Sand in their eyes
column34: the Sand is verry fine and rises in clouds from the Points and bars of the river
column35: I may Say that dureing those winds we eat Drink & breeth a prepotion of Sand. [Lewis
column36: April 25
column37: 1805] Thursday April 25th 1805. The wind was more moderate this morning
column38: tho still hard; we set out at an early hour. the water friezed on the oars this morning as the men rowed. about 10 oclock A.M. the wind began to blow so violently that we were obliged to lye too. my dog had been absent during the last night
column39: and I was fearfull we had lost him altogether
column40: however
column41: much to my satisfaction he joined us at 8 Oclock this morning. The wind had been so unfavorable to our progress for several days past
column42: and seeing but little prospect of a favourable chang; knowing that the river was crooked
column43: from the report of the hunters who were out yesterday
column44: and beleiving that we were at no very great distance from the Yellow stone River; I determined
column45: in order as mush as possible to avoid detention
column46: to proceed by land with a few men to the entrance of that river and make the necessary observations to determine it's position
column47: which I hoped to effect by the time that Capt. Clark could arrive with the party; accordingly I set out at 1 t OCk. on the Lard. side
column48: accompanyed by four men. we proceeded about four miles
column49: when falling in with some bufaloe I killed a yearling calf
column50: which was in good order; we soon cooked and made a hearty meal of a part of it
column51: and renewed our march our rout lay along the foot of the river hills. when we had proceeded about four miles
column52: I ascended the hills from whence I had a most pleasing view of the country
column53: perticularly of the wide and fertile values formed by the missouri and the yellowstone rivers
column54: which occasionally unmasked by the wood on their borders disclose their meanderings for many miles in their passage through these delightfull tracts of country. I could not discover the junction of the rivers immediately
column55: they being concealed by the woods
column56: however
column57: sensible that it could not be distant I determined to encamp on the bank of the Yellow stone river which made it's appearance about 2 miles South of me. the whol face of the country was covered with herds of Buffaloe
column58: Elk & Antelopes; deer are also abundant
column59: but keep themselves more concealed in the woodland. the buffaloe Elk and Antelope are so gentle that we pass near them while feeding
column60: without apearing to excite any alarm among them
column61: and when we attract their attention
column62: they frequently approach us more nearly to discover what we are
column63: and in some instances pursue us a considerable distance apparenly with that view.--in our way to the place I had determined to encamp
column64: we met with two large herds of buffaloe
column65: of which we killed three cows and a calf. two of the former
column66: wer but lean
column67: we therefore took their tongues and a part of their marrow-bones only. I then proceeded to the place of our encampment with two of the men
column68: taking with us the Calf and marrowbones
column69: while the other two remained
column70: with orders to dress the cow that was in tolerable order
column71: and hang the meat out of the reach of the wolves
column72: a precaution indispensible to it's safe keeping
column73: even for a night. we encamped on the bank of the yellowstone river
column74: 2 miles South of it's confluence with the Missouri. On rejoining Capt. Clark
column75: the 26th in the evening
column76: he informed me
column77: that at 5 P.M. after I left him the wind abated in some measure and he proceeded a few miles further and encamped. [Clark
column78: April 25
column79: 1805] 25th of April Thursday 1805 The wind was moderate & ahead this morning
column80: we Set out at an early hour The morning cold
column81: Some flying Clouds to be Seen
column82: the wind from the N. ice collected on the ores this morning
column83: the wind increased and became So violent about 1 oClock we were obliged to lay by our Canoes haveing taken in Some water
column84: the Dog which was lost yesterday
column85: joined us this morning.

column1: finding that the winds retarded our progression for maney days past
column2: and no apparance of an alteration
column3: and the river being Crooked that we could never have 3 miles fair wind
column4: Capt. Lewis concluded to go by land as far as the Rochejhone or yellow Stone river
column5: which we expect is at no great distance by land and make Some Selestial observations to find the Situation of its mouth
column6: and by that measure not detain the Perogues at that place any time for the purpose of makeing those necessary observations he took 4 men & proceeded on up the Missouri on the L. Side
column7: at 5 oClock the wind luled and we proceeded on and incamped. [Lewis
column8: April 26
column9: 1805] Friday April 26th 1805. This morning I dispatched Joseph Fields up the yellowstone river with orders to examine it as far as he could conveniently and return the same evening; two others were directed to bring in the meat we had killed last evening
column10: while I proceeded down the river with one man in order to take a view of the confluence of this great river with the Missouri
column11: which we found to be two miles distant on a direct line N. W. from our encampment. the bottom land on the lower side of the yellowstone river near it's mouth for about one mile in width appears to be subject to inundation; while that on the opposite side of the Missouri and the point formed by the junction of these rivers is of the common elivation
column12: say from twelve to 18 feet above the level of the water
column13: and of course not liable to be overflown except in extreem high water
column14: which dose not appear to be very frequent there is more timber in the neighbourhood of the junction of these rivers
column15: and on the Missouri as far below as the White earth river
column16: than there is on any part of the Missouri above the entrance of the Chyenne river to this place. the timber consists principally of Cottonwood
column17: with some small elm
column18: ash and boxalder. the under growth on the sandbars and verge of the river is the small leafed willow; the low bottoms
column19: rose bushes which rise to three or four feet high
column20: the redburry
column21: servicebury
column22: and the redwood; the high bottoms are of two discriptions either timbered or open; the first lies next to the river and it's under brush is the same with that of the low timbered bottoms with the addition of the broad leafed willow
column23: Goosbury
column24: choke cherry
column25: purple currant; and honeysuckle bushis; the open bottoms border on the hills
column26: and are covered in many parts by the wild hyssop which rises to the hight of two feet. I observe that the Antelope
column27: Buffaloe Elk and deer feed on this herb; the willow of the sandbars also furnish a favorite winter food to these anamals as well as the growse
column28: the porcupine
column29: hare
column30: and rabbit. about 12 Olock I heard the discharge of several guns at the junction of the rivers
column31: which announced to me the arrival of the paty with Capt Clark; I afterwards learnt that they had fired on some buffaloe which they met with at that place
column32: and of which they killed a cow and several Calves; the latter are now fine veal. I dispatched one of the men to Capt Clark requesting him to send up a canoe to take down the meat we had killed and our baggage to his encampmt
column33: which was accordingly complyed with. after I had completed my observations in the evening I walked down and joined the party at their encampment on the point of land fromed by the junction of the rivers; found them all in good health
column34: and much pleased at having arrived at this long wished for spot
column35: and in order to add in some measure to the general pleasure which seemed to pervade our little community
column36: we ordered a dram to be issued to each person; this soon produced the fiddle
column37: and they spent the evening with much hilarity
column38: singing & dancing
column39: and seemed as perfectly to forget their past toils
column40: as they appeared regardless of those to come. in the evening
column41: the man I had sent up the river this morning returned
column42: and reported that he had ascended it about eight miles on a streight line; that he found it crooked
column43: meandering from side to side of the valley formed by it; which is from four to five miles wide. the corrent of the river gentle
column44: and it's bed much interrupted and broken by sandbars; at the distance of five miles he passed a large Island well covered with timber
column45: and three miles higher a large creek falls in on the S. E. sides above a high bluff in which there are several stratas of coal. the country bordering on this river as far as he could percieve
column46: like that of the Missouri
column47: consisted of open plains. he saw several of the bighorned anamals in the couse of his walk; but they were so shy that he could not get a shoot at them; he found a large horn of one of these anamals which he brought with him. the bed of the yellowstone river is entirely composed of sand and mud
column48: not a stone of any kind to be seen in it near it's entrance. Capt Clark measured these rivers just above their confluence; found the bed of the Missouri 520 yards wide
column49: the water occupying 330. it's channel deep. the yellowstone river including it's sandbar
column50: 858 yds. of which
column51: the water occupyed 297 yards; the depest part 12 feet; it was falling at this time & appeard to be nearly at it's summer tide.--the Indians inform that the yellowstone river is navigable for perogues and canoes nearly to it's source in the Rocky Mountains
column52: and that in it's course near these mountains it passes within less than half a day's march of a navigable part of the Missouri. it's extreem sources are adjacent to those of the Missouri
column53: river platte
column54: and I think probably with some of the South branch of the Columbia river. the first part of its course lies through a mountanous rocky country tho well timbered and in many parts fertile; the middle
column55: and much the most extensive portion of the river lies through a delightfull rich and fertile country
column56: well covered with timber
column57: intersperced with plains and meadows
column58: and well watered; it is some what broken in many parts. the lower portion consists of fertile open plains and meadows almost entirely
column59: tho it possesses a considerable proportion of timber on it's borders. the current of the upper portion is extreemly rappid
column60: that of the middle and lower portions much more gentle than the Missouri. the water of this river is turbid
column61: tho dose not possess as much sediment as that of the Missouri. this river in it's course recieves the waters of many large tributary strains principally from the S. E. of which the most considerable are the Tongue and bighorn rivers the former is much the largest
column62: and heads with the river Platte and Bighorn river
column63: as dose the latter with the Tongue river and the river Platte.--a suficient quantity of limestone may be readily procured for building near the junction of the Missouri and yellowstone rivers. I could observe no regular stratas of it
column64: tho it lies on the sides of the river hills in large irregular masses
column65: in considerable quantities; it is of a light colour
column66: and appears to be of an excellent quality.- [Clark
column67: April 26
column68: 1805] 26th of April Friday 1805 last night was verry Cold. the Thermometer Stood at 32 abov 0 this morning. I Set out at an early hour
column69: as it was cold I walked on the bank
column70: & in my walk Shot a beaver & 2 Deer
column71: one of the Deer in tolerable order
column72: the low bottom of the river is generaly Covered with wood willows & rose bushes
column73: red berry
column74: wild Cherry & red or arrow wood intersperced with glades The timber is Cottonwood principally
column75: Elm Small ash also furnish a portion of the timber
column76: The Clay of the bluffs appear much whiter than below
column77: and Contain Several Stratums of Coal
column78: on the hill Sides I observe pebbles of different Size & Colour--The river has been riseing for Several days
column79: & raised 3 inches last night
column80: at 12 oClock arrived at the forks of the Roche Johne & Missouri and formed a Camp on the point Soon after George Drewyer Came from Capt Lewis & informed me that he was a little way up the Roche johne and would join me this evining
column81: I Sent a canoe up to Capt Lewis and proceeded measure the width of the rivers
column82: and find the debth. The Missouri is 520 yards wide above the point of yellow Stone and the water covers 330 yards; the YellowStone River is 858 yards wide includeing its Sand bar
column83: the water covers 297 yards and the deepest part is 12 feet water
column84: it is at this time falling
column85: the Missouri rising The Indians inform that the yellow Stone River is navagable for Perogues to near its Source in the Rocky Mountains
column86: it has many tributary Streams
column87: principally on the S. E. Side
column88: and heads at no great distance from the Missouri
column89: the largest rivers which fall into it is Tongue river which heads with the waters of River Platt
column90: and Big horn river which also heads with Platt & Tongue R the current of this river is Said to be rapid near its mouth it is verry jentle
column91: and its water is of a whitish colour much Clearer of Sediment than the Missouri. the Countrey on this river is Said to be broken in its whole Course & Contains a great deel of wood
column92: the countrey about its mouth is verry fine
column93: the bottoms on either Side is wooded with Cotton wood
column95: Elm &c. near the banks of the river back is higher bottoms and Covered with red berry
column96: Goose berry & rose bushes &. interspersed with Small open Glades
column97: and near the high land is Generally open rich bottoms--at our arrival at the forks I observed a Drove of Buffalow Cows & Calves on a Sand bar in the point
column98: I directed the men to kill the fattest Cow
column100: which they did and let the others pass

column1: Capt Lewis joined me in the evening after takeing equal altitudes a little way up the YellowStone river the Countrey in every direction is plains except the moist bottoms of the river
column2: which are covered with Some indifferent timber Such as Cotton wood Elm & Small ash
column3: with different kind of Stubs & bushes in the forks about 1 mile from the point at which place the 2 rivers are near each other a butifull low leavel plain Commences
column4: and extends up the Missourie & back
column5: this plain is narrow at its commencement and widens as the Missouri bends north
column6: and is bordered by an extencive wood land for many miles up the yellow Stone river
column7: this low plain is not Subject to over flow
column8: appear to be a few inches above high water mark and affords a butifull commanding Situation for a fort near the commencement of the Prarie
column9: about ____ miles from the Point & ____ yards from the Missouri a Small lake is Situated
column10: from this lake the plain rises gradually to a high butifull Countrey
column11: the low Plain continues for Some distance up both rivers on the Yellow Stone it is wide & butifull opsd. the point on the S. Side is Some high timbered land
column12: about 11/2 miles below on the Same Side a little distance from the water is an elivated plain--Several of the party was up the yellow Stone R Several miles
column13: & informed that it meandered throught a butifull Countrey Joseph Fields discovered a large Creek falling into the Yellowstone River on the S E Side 8 miles up near which he Saw a big horn animal
column14: he found in the Prarie the horn of one of those animals which was large and appeared to have laid Several years I Saw maney buffalow dead on the banks of the river in different places Some of them eaten by the white bears & wolves all except the Skin & bones
column15: others entire
column16: those animals either drounded in attempting to Cross on the ice dureing the winter or Swiming across to bluff banks where they Could not get out & too weak to return we Saw several in this Situation.emence numbers of antelopes in the forks of the river
column17: Buffalow & Elk & Deer is also plenty beaver is in every bend. I observe that the Magpie Goose duck & Eagle all have their nests in the Same neighbourhood
column18: and it is not uncommon for the Magpie to build in a few rods of the eagle
column19: the nests of this bird is built verry Strong with Sticks Covered verry thickly with one or more places through which they enter or escape
column20: the Goose I make no doubt falls a pray to those vicious eaglesThis morning I walked through the point formed by the junction of the rivers; the woodland extends about a mile
column21: when the rivers approach each other within less than half a mile; here a beatifull level low plain commences and extends up both rivers for many miles
column22: widening as the rivers recede from each other
column23: and extending back half a mile to a plain about 12 feet higher than itself; the low plain appears to be a few inches higher than high water mark and of course will not be liable to be overflown; tho where it joins the high plain a part of the Missouri when at it's greatest hight
column24: passes through a channel of 60 or 70 yards wide and falls into the yellowstone river. on the Missouri about 21/2 miles from the entrance of the yellowstone river
column25: and between this high and low plain
column26: a small lake is situated about 200 yards wide extending along the edge of the high plain parallel with the Missouri about one mile. on the point of the high plain at the lower extremity of this lake I think would be the most eligible site for an establishment. between this low plain and the Yellowstone river their is an extensive body of timbered land extending up the river for many miles. this site recommended is about 400 yards distant from the Missouri and about double that distance from the river yellowstone; from it the high plain
column27: rising very gradually
column28: extends back about three miles to the hills
column29: and continues with the same width between these hills and the timbered land on the yellowstone river
column30: up that stream
column31: for seven or eight miles; and is one of the hadsomest plains I ever beheld. on the Missouri side the hills sircumscribe it's width
column32: & at the distance of three miles up that river from this site
column33: it is not more than 400 yards wide. Capt Clark thinks that the lower extremity of the low plane would be most eligible for this establishment; it is true that it is much nearer both rivers
column34: and might answer very well
column35: but I think it reather too low to venture a permanent establishment
column36: particularly if built of brick or other durable materials
column37: at any considerable expence; for so capricious
column38: and versatile are these rivers
column39: that it is difficult to say how long it will be
column40: untill they direct the force of their currents against this narrow part of the low plain
column41: which when they do
column42: must shortly yeald to their influence; in such case a few years only would be necessary
column43: for the annihilation of the plain
column44: and with it the fortification.--I continued my walk on shore; at 11 A.M. the wind became very hard from N. W. insomuch that the perogues and canoes were unable either to proceede or pass the river to me; I was under the necessity therefore of shooting a goose and cooking it for my dinner. the wind abated about 4. P.M. and the party proceeded tho I could not conveniently join them untill night. altho game is very abundant and gentle
column45: we only kill as much as is necessary for food. I believe that two good hunters could conveniently supply a regiment with provisions. for several days past we have observed a great number of buffaloe lying dead on the shore
column46: some of them entire and others partly devoured by the wolves and bear. those anamals either drownded during the winter in attempting to pass the river on the ice during the winter or by swiming acrss at present to bluff banks which they are unable to ascend
column47: and feeling themselves too weak to return remain and perish for the want of food; in this situation we met with several little parties of them.--beaver are very abundant
column48: the party kill several of them every day. The Eagles
column49: Magpies
column50: and gees have their nests in trees adjacent to each other; the magpye particularly appears fond of building near the Eagle
column51: as we scarcely see an Eagle's nest unaccompanyed with two or three Magpies nests within a short distance.--The bald Eagle are more abundant here than I ever observed them in any part of the country. [Clark
column52: April 27
column53: 1805] 27th of April Satturday 1805 after take the azmuth of the Sun & brackfasting we Set out wind moderate & a head
column54: at 11 oClock the wind rose and continued to blow verry hard a head from the N. W. untill 4 oClock P M
column55: which blew the Sand off the Points in Such clouds as almost Covered us on the opposit bank
column56: at 4 I Set out from my unpleasent Situation and proceeded on
column57: Capt. Lewis walked on Shore in the Point to examine & view the Countrey and could not get to the boats untill night
column58: Saw great numbers of Goats or antilopes
column59: Elk
column60: Swan Gees & Ducks
column61: no buffalow to day I Saw Several beaver and much Sign
column62: I Shot one in the head which imediately Sunk
column63: altho the game of different kinds are in abundance we Kill nothing but what we can make [Lewis
column64: April 28
column65: 1805] Sunday April 28th 1805. Set out this morning at an early hour; the wind was favourable and we employed our sails to advantage. Capt Clark walked on shore this morning
column66: and I proceeded with the party. the country through which we passed today is open as usual and very broken on both sides near the river hills
column67: the bottoms are level fertile and partially covered with timber. the hills and bluffs exhibit their usual mineral appearances
column68: some birnt hills but no appearance of Pumicestone; coal is in great abundance and the salts still increase in quantity; the banks of the river and sandbars are incrusted with it in many places and appear perfectly white as if covered with snow or frost.--the woods are now green
column69: tho the plains and meadows appear to abate of the verdure those below exhibited some days past. we past three small runs today. two falling in on the Stard. and one on the Lard. side
column70: they are but small afford but little water and head a few miles back in the hills. we saw great quantities of game today; consisting of the common and mule deer
column71: Elk
column72: Buffaloe
column73: and Antelopes; also four brown bear
column74: one of which was fired on and wounded by one of the party but we did not get it; the beaver have cut great quantities of timber; saw a tree nearly 3 feet in diameter that had been felled by them. Capt. Clark in the course of his walk killed a deer and a goose; & saw three black bear; he thinks the bottoms are not so wide as they have been for some days past.

column3: 1805] 28th of April Sunday 1805 a fine day river falling
column4: wind favourable from the S. E. and moderate
column5: I walked on Shore to view the Countrey
column6: from the top of the high hills
column7: I beheld a broken & open Countrey on both Sides
column8: near the river Some verry handsom low plains
column9: I killd. a Deer & a goose
column10: Saw three black bear great numbers of Elk antelopes & 2 Gangues of Buffalow
column11: the hills & Bluffs Shew the Straturs of Coal
column12: and burnt appearances in maney places
column13: in and about them I could find no appearance of Pumice Stone
column14: the wood land have a green appearance
column15: the Plains do not look So green as below
column16: The bottoms are not So wide this afternoon as below Saw four bear this evening
column17: one of the men Shot at one of them. The Antilopes are nearly red
column18: on that part which is Subject to change i e the Sides & 2/3 of the back from the head
column19: the other part as white as Snow
column20: 2 Small runs fall in on the S. Side and one this evening on the Lard Side those runs head at a fiew miles in the hills and discharge but little water
column21: the Bluffs in this part as also below Shew different Straturs of Coal or carbonated wood
column22: and Coloured earth
column23: such as dark brown
column24: yellow a lightish brown
column25: & a dark red &c. [Lewis
column26: April 29
column27: 1805] Monday April 29th 1805. Set out this morning at the usual hour; the wind was moderate; I walked on shore with one man. about 8 A.M. we fell in with two brown or yellow bear; both of which we wounded; one of them made his escape
column28: the other after my firing on him pursued me seventy or eighty yards
column29: but fortunately had been so badly wounded that he was unable to pursue so closely as to prevent my charging my gun; we again repeated our fir and killed him. it was a male not fully grown
column30: we estimated his weight at 300 lbs. not having the means of ascertaining it precisely. The legs of this bear are somewhat longer than those of the black
column31: as are it's tallons and tusks incomparably larger and longer. the testicles
column32: which in the black bear are placed pretty well back between the thyes and contained in one pouch like those of the dog and most quadrupeds
column33: are in the yellow or brown bear placed much further forward
column34: and are suspended in seperate pouches from two to four inches asunder; it's colour is yellowish brown
column35: the eyes small
column36: black
column37: and piercing; the front of the fore legs near the feet is usually black; the fur is finer thicker and deeper than that of the black bear. these are all the particulars in which this anamal appeared to me to differ from the black bear; it is a much more furious and formidable anamal
column38: and will frequently pursue the hunter when wounded. it is asstonishing to see the wounds they will bear before they can be put to death. the Indians may well fear this anamal equiped as they generally are with their bows and arrows or indifferent fuzees
column39: but in the hands of skillfull riflemen they are by no means as formidable or dangerous as they have been represented. game is still very abundant we can scarcely cast our eyes in any direction without percieving deer Elk Buffaloe or Antelopes. The quantity of wolves appear to increase in the same proportion; they generally hunt in parties of six eight or ten; they kill a great number of the Antelopes at this season; the Antelopes are yet meagre and the females are big with young; the wolves take them most generally in attempting to swim the river; in this manner my dog caught one drowned it and brought it on shore; they are but clumsey swimers
column40: tho on land when in good order
column41: they are extreemly fleet and dureable. we have frequently seen the wolves in pursuit of the Antelope in the plains; they appear to decoy a single one from a flock
column42: and then pursue it
column43: alturnately relieving each other untill they take it. on joining Capt Clark he informed me that he had seen a female and faun of the bighorned anamal; that they ran for some distance with great aparent ease along the side of the river bluff where it was almost perpendicular; two of the party fired on them while in motion without effect. we took the flesh of the bear on board and proceeded. Capt. Clark walked on shore this evening
column44: killed a deer
column45: and saw several of the bighorned anamals. there is more appearance of coal today than we have yet seen
column46: the stratas are 6 feet thick in some instances; the earth has been birnt in many places
column47: and always appears in stratas on the same level with the stratas of coal. we came too this evening in the mouth of a little river
column48: which falls in on the Stard. side. This stream is about 50 yards wide from bank to bank; the water occupyes about 15 yards. the banks are of earth only
column49: abrupt
column50: tho not high--the bed
column51: is of mud principally. Capt Clark
column52: who was up this streeam about three miles
column53: informed me that it continued about the same width
column54: that it's current was gentle and it appeared navigable for perogus it meanders through an extensive
column55: fertile
column56: and beautifull vally as far as could bee seen about N. 30°W. there was but one solitary tree to be seen on the banks of this river after it left the bottom of the Missouri. the water of this river is clear
column57: with a brownish yelow tint. here the highlands receede from the Missouri
column58: leaving the vally formed by the river from seven to eight miles wide
column59: and reather lower then usual.- This stream my friend Capt. C. named Marthas river

column3: 1805] 29th of April Monday 1805 Set out this morning at the usial hour. the wind is moderate & from the N E had not proceeded far eer we Saw a female & her faun of the Bighorn animal on the top of a Bluff lying
column4: the noise we made allarmed them and they came down on the Side of the bluff which had but little Slope being nearly purpindicular
column5: I directed two men to kill those anamals
column6: one went on the top and the other man near the water they had two Shots at the doe while in motion without effect
column7: Those animals run & Skiped about with great ease on this declivity & appeared to prefur it to the leavel bottom or plain. Capt Lewis & one man walkd on Shore and he killed a yellow Bear & the man with him wounded one other
column8: after getting the flesh of the bear on bord which was not far from the place we brackfast
column9: we proceeded on Saw 4 gangus of buffalow and great numbers of Antelopes in every direction also Saw Elk and Several wolves
column10: I walked on Shore in the evening & killed a Deer which was So meager as to be unfit for use The hills Contain more Coal
column11: and has a greater appearance of being burnt that below
column12: the burnt parts appear on a parrilel with the Stratiums of Coal
column13: we Came too in the mouth of a Little river on the S. S. which is about 50 or 60 yards from bank to bank
column14: I was up this Stream 3 miles it continues its width and glides with a gentle Current
column15: its water is about 15 yards wide at this time
column16: and appears to be navagable for Canoes &c. it meanders through a butifull & extencive vallie as far as can be Seen about N 30° W. I saw only a Single tree in this fertile vallie The water of the River is clear of a yellowish Colour
column17: we call this river Martheys river in honor to the Selebrated M. FHere the high land widen from five to Eight miles and much lower than below
column18: Saw Several of the big horn animals this evening. The Wolves distroy great numbers of the antilopes by decoying those animals Singularly out in the plains and prosueing them alternetly
column19: those antelopes are Curious and will approach any thing which appears in motion near them &c. [Lewis
column20: April 30
column21: 1805] Tuesday April 30th 1805. Set out at sunrise. the wind blew hard all last night
column22: and continued to blow pretty hard all day
column23: but not so much
column24: as to compell us to ly by. the country as usual is bare of timber; the river bottoms are level and fertile and extensive
column25: but possess but little timber and that of an indifferent quality even of it's kind; principally low cottonwood
column26: either too small for building
column27: or for plank or broken and dead at top and unsound in the center of the trunk. saw great quantities of game as usual. Capt. Clark walked on shore the greater part of the day
column28: past some old Indian lodges built of drift wood; they appear to be of antient date and not recently inhabited. I walked on shore this evening and killed a buck Elk
column29: in tolerable order; it appeared to me to be the largest I had seen
column30: and was therefore induced to measure it; found it five feet three inches from the point of the hoof
column31: to the top of the sholders; the leg and hoof being placed as nearly as possible in the same position they would have been had the anamal been standing. [Clark
column32: April 30
column33: 1805] 30th of April Tuesday 1805 The wind blew hard from the N E all last night
column34: we Set out at Sunrise the wind blew hard the greater part of the day and part of the time favourable
column35: we did not lie by to day on account of the wind I walked on Shore to day our interpreter & his Squar followed
column36: in my walk the Squar found & brought me a bush Something like the Current
column37: which She Said bore a delicious froot and that great quantites grew on the Rocky Mountains
