Those Skit lutes are much better behaved than the War ci a cum indeed we found a great alteration in the Conduct of them all this morning, the Sight of our Sentinal on his post at the gate, together with our deturmined proseedure of putting all out at Sun Set has made this reform in those War ci a corns who is foward impertinant an thieveish.The nativs all leave us the fort this evening before Sun Set without being told or desired to do So--we had Sinks dug & a Sentinal box made- a Skit lute brought a gun which he requested me to have repared, it only wanted a Screw flattened So as to Catch, I put a flint into his gun & he presented me in return a peck of Wappato for payment, I gave him piece of a Sheap Skin and a Small piece of blue Cloth to Cover his lock for which he was much pleased and gave me in return Some roots &c.I Saw flies and different kinds of insects in motion to day--Snakes are yet to be Seen and Snales without Covers is Common and verry large water fowls of various kinds are in great numbers in the rivers and Creeks and the sides of Meriwethers Bay near us but excessively wild- the fore part of this night fair and ClearWith the party of Clat Sops who visited us last was a man of much lighter Coloured than the nativs are generaly, he was freckled with long duskey red hair, about 25 years of age, and must Certainly be half white at least, this man appeared to understand more of the English language than the others of his party, but did not Speak a word of English, he possessed all the habits of the indians [Lewis, January 1, 1806] Fort Clatsop 1806. January 1st Tuesday. This morning I was awoke at an early hour by the discharge of a volley of small arms, which were fired by our party in front of our quarters to usher in the new year; this was the only mark of rispect which we had it in our power to pay this celebrated day. our repast of this day tho better than that of Christmass, consisted principally in the anticipation of the 1st day of January 1807, when in the bosom of our friends we hope to participate in the mirth and hilarity of the day, and when with the zest given by the recollection of the present, we shall completely, both mentally and corporally, enjoy the repast which the hand of civilization has prepared for us. at present we were content with eating our boiled Elk and wappetoe, and solacing our thirst with our only beverage pure water. two of our hunters who set out this morning reterned in the evening having killed two bucks elk; they presented Capt. Clark and myself each a marrow-bone and tonge, on which we suped. visited today by a few of the Clotsops who brought some roots and burries for the purpose of trading with us. we were uneasy with rispect to two of our men, Willard and Wiser, who were dispatched on the 28th ulto. with the saltmakers, and were directed to return immediately; their not having returned induces us to believe it probable that they have missed their way.--our fourtification being now completed we issued an order for the more exact and uniform dicipline and government of the garrison. (see orderly book 1st January 1806).- [Clark, January 1, 1806] January 1st Wednesday 1806 This morning proved cloudy with moderate rain, after a pleasent worm night during which there fell but little rain--This morning at Day we wer Saluted from the party without, wishing us a "hapy new year" a Shout and discharge of their arms--no Indians to be Seen this morning- they left the place of their encampment dureing the last night The work of our houses and fort being now Complete, we Ishued an order in which we pointed out the rules & regulations for the government of the Party in respect to the Indians as also for the Safty and protection of our Selves &c. [Clark, January 1, 1806] Fort Clatsop 1806 Wednesday the 1st of January This morning I was awoke at an early hour by the discharge of a Volley of Small arms, which were fired by our party in front of our quarters to usher in the new year, this was the only mark of respect which we had it in our power to pay this Selibrated day. our repast of this day tho better than that of Christmas Consisted principally in the anticipation of the 1st day of January 1807, when in the bosom of our friends we hope to participate in the mirth and hilarity of the day, and when with the relish given by the recollection of the present, we Shall Completely, both mentally and Corparally, the repast which the hand of Civilization has produced for us. at present we were Content with eating our boiled Elk and Wappato, and Solacing our thirst with our only beverage pure water. two of our hunters who Set out this morning returned in the evening haveing killed two Buck Elks; they presented Capt. Lewis and my Self each a marrow bone and tongue on which we Suped--we are visited to day by a fiew of the Clatsops by water they brought some roots and berries for the purpose of tradeing with us. our fortification being now Complete we issue an order for the more exact and uniform dicipline and government of the garrison. (See orderly book Jany 2d 1806)

column3: 1806] Fort Clatsop
column4: January 1st 1806 The fort being now completed
column5: the Commanding officers think proper to direct that the guard shall as usual consist of one Sergeant and three privates
column6: and that the same be regularly relieved each morning at sun rise. The post of the new guard shall be in the room of the Sergeants rispectivly commanding the same. the centinel shall be posted
column7: both day and night
column8: on the parade in front of the commanding offercers quarters; tho should he at any time think proper to remove himself to any other part of the fort
column9: in order the better to inform himself of the desighns or approach of any party of savages
column10: he is not only at liberty
column11: but is hereby required to do so. It shall be the duty of the centinel also to announce the arrival of all parties of Indians to the Sergeant of the Guard
column12: who shall immediately report the same to the Commanding officers.The Commanding Officers require and charge the Garrison to treat the natives in a friendly manner; nor will they be permitted at any time
column13: to abuse
column14: assault or strike them; unless such abuse assault or stroke be first given by the natives. nevertheless it shall be right for any individual
column15: in a peaceable manner
column16: to refuse admittance to
column17: or put out of his room
column18: any native who may become troublesome to him; and should such native refuse to go when requested
column19: or attempt to enter their rooms after being forbidden to do so; it shall be the duty of the Sergeant of the guard on information of the same
column20: to put such native out of the fort and see that he is not again admitted during that day unless specially permitted; and the Sergeant of the guard may for this purpose imploy such coercive measures (not extending to the taking of life) as shall at his discretion be deemed necessary to effect the same.When any native shall be detected in theft
column21: the Sergt. of the guard shall immediately inform the Commanding offercers of the same
column22: to the end that such measures may be pursued with rispect to the culprit as they shall think most expedient.At sunset on each day
column23: the Sergt. attended by the interpreter Charbono and two of his guard
column24: will collect and put out of the fort
column25: all Indians except such as may specially be permitted to remain by the Commanding offercers
column26: nor shall they be again admitted untill the main gate be opened the ensuing morning.At Sunset
column27: or immediately after the Indians have been dismissed
column28: both gates shall be shut
column29: and secured
column30: and the main gate locked and continue so untill sunrise the next morning; the water-gate may be used freely by the Garrison for the purpose of passing and repassing at all times
column31: tho from sunset
column32: untill sunrise
column33: it shall be the duty of the centinel
column34: to open the gate for
column35: and shut it after all persons passing and repassing
column36: suffering the same never to remain unfixed long than is absolutely necessary.It shall be the duty of the Sergt. of the guard to keep the kee of the Meat house
column37: and to cause the guard to keep regular fires therein when the same may be necessary; and also once at least in 24 hours to visit the canoes and see that they are safely secured; and shall further on each morning after he is relieved
column38: make his report verbally to the Commandg officers.Each mess being furnished with an ax
column39: they are directed to deposit in the room of the commanding offercers all other public tools of which they are possessed; nor shall the same at any time hereafter be taken from the said deposit without the knoledge and permission of the commanding officers; and any individual so borrowing the tools are strictly required to bring the same back the moment he has ceased to use them
column40: and no case shall they be permited to keep them out all night.Any individual selling or disposing of any tool or iron or steel instrument
column41: arms
column42: accoutrements or ammunicion
column43: shall be deemed guilty of a breach of this order
column44: and shall be tryed and punished accordingly.the tools loaned to John Shields are excepted from the restrictions of this order. [Lewis
column45: January 2
column46: 1806] Thursday
column47: January 2nd 1806 Sent out a party of men and brought in the two Elk which were killed yesterday. Willard and Wiser have not yet returned nor have a party of hunters returned who set out on the 26th Ulto. the Indians who visited yesterday left us at 1 P M today after having disposed of their roots and berries for a few fishinghooks and some other small articles. we are infested with swarms of flees already in our new habitations; the presumption is therefore strong that we shall not devest ourselves of this intolerably troublesome vermin during our residence here. The large
column48: and small or whistling swan
column49: sand hill Crane
column50: large and small gees
column51: brown and white brant
column52: Cormorant
column53: duckan mallard
column54: Canvisback duck
column55: and several other species of ducks
column56: still remain with us; tho I do not think that they are as plenty as on our first arrival in the neighbourhood. Drewyer visited his traps and took an otter. the fur of both the beaver and otter in this country are extreemly good; those annamals are tolerably plenty near the sea coast
column57: and on the small Creeks and rivers as high as the grand rappids
column58: but are by no means as much so as on the upper part of the Missouri. [Clark
column59: January 2
column60: 1806] January 2nd Thursday 1806. A Cloudy rainey morning after a wet night. dispatched 12 Men for the two Elk Killed yesterday which they brought in at 11 oClock. the day proved Cloudy and wet
column61: the Indians left us at 1 oClock P. M
column62: Drewyer visited his traps which had one otter in one of them. The flees are verry troublesom
column63: our huts have alreadey Sworms of those disagreeable insects in them
column64: and I fear we Shall not get rid of them dureing our delay at this place. [Clark
column65: January 2
column66: 1806] Thursday 2nd of January 1806. Sent out a party of men and brought in the two Elk which was killed yesterday. Willard & Wiser have not yet returned nor have a party of hunters who Set out on the 26th ulto the Indians who visited us yesterday left us at 1 P. M to day after haveing disposed of their roots and berries for a fiew fishing hooks and Some other Small articles. we are infestd. with Sworms of flees already in our new habatations; the presumption is therefore Strong that we Shall not devest our Selves of this intolerably troublesom vermin dureing our residence here. The large
column67: & Small or whistling Swan
column68: Sand hill crane
column69: large & Small Gees
column70: brown and white brant
column71: Comorant
column72: Duckanmallard
column73: canvis back duck
column74: and Several other Species of Ducks Still remain with us; tho I doe not think they are as plenty as on our first arrival in the neighbourhood. Drewyer visit his traps at took out an otter. the fur of both the beaver and otter as also the rackoon in this countrey are extreemly good; those animals are tolerably plenty near the Sea coast
column75: on the Small creeks and rivers as high as the grand Rapids.

column3: 1806] Friday January 3d 1806. At 11 A.M. we were visited by our near neighbours
column4: Chief or Tia
column5: Como-wool; alias Conia and six Clatsops. they brought for sale some roots buries and three dogs also a small quantity of fresh blubber. this blubber they informed us they had obtained from their neighbours the Callamucksz who inhabit the coast to the S. E. near whose vilage a whale had recently perished. this blubber the Indians eat and esteeme it excellent food. our party from necessaty having been obliged to subsist some lenth of time on dogs have now become extreemly fond of their flesh; it is worthy of remark that while we lived principally on the flesh of this anamal we were much more healthy strong and more fleshey than we had been since we left the Buffaloe country. for my own part I have become so perfectly reconciled to the dog that I think it an agreeable food and would prefer it vastly to lean Venison or Elk. a small Crow
column6: the blue crested Corvus and the smaller corvus with a white brest
column7: the little brown ren
column8: a large brown sparrow
column9: the bald Eagle and the beatifull Buzzard of the columbia still continue with us.--Sent Sergt. Gass and George Shannon to the saltmakers who are somewhere on the coast to the S. W. of us
column10: to enquire after Willard and Wiser who have not yet returned. Reubin Fields Collins and Pots the hunters who set out on the 26th Ulto. returned this evening after dark. they reported that they had been about 15 Miles up the river at the head of the bay just below us and had hunted the country from thence down on the East side of the river
column11: even to a considerable distance from it and had proved unsuccessful) having killed one deer and a few fowls
column12: barely as much as subsisted them. this reminded us of the necessity of taking time by the forelock
column13: and keep out several parties while we have yet a little meat beforehand.I gave the Chief Comowooll a pare of sattin breechies with which he appeared much pleased. [Clark
column14: January 3
column15: 1806] January 3rd Friday 1806 The Sun rose fair this morning for the first time for Six weeks past
column16: the Clouds Soon obscure it from our view
column17: and a Shower of rain Suckceededlast night we had Sharp lightening a hard thunder Suckceeded with heavy Showers of hail
column18: and rain
column19: which Continud with intervales of fair moon Shine dureing the night. Sent out Sergt. Gass & 2 men to the Salt makers with a vew to know what is the Cause of the delay of 2 of our party Willard & Wiser who we are uneasy about
column20: as they were to have been back 6 days ago. [Clark
column21: January 3
column22: 1806] Friday the 3rd January 1806 At 11 A. m. we were visited by our near neighbour Chief (or Tia) Co mo wool alias Conia and Six Clat sops. they brought for Sale Some roots berries and 3 Dogs also a Small quantity of fresh blubber. this blubber they informed us they had obtained from their neighbours the Cal la mox who inhabit the coast to the S. E near one of their Villages a Whale had recently perished. this blubber the Indians eat and esteem it excellent food. our party from necescity have been obliged to Subsist Some length of time on dogs have now become extreamly fond of their flesh; it is worthey of remark that while we lived principally on the flesh of this animal we wer much more helthy Strong and more fleshey then we have been Sence we left the Buffalow Country. as for my own part I have not become reconsiled to the taste of this animal as yet. a Small Crow
column23: the blue Crested Corvus and the Smaller Corvus with a white breast
column24: the little brown ren
column25: and a large brown Sparrow
column26: the bald Eagle
column27: and the butifull Buzzard of the Columbia Still Continue with us
column28: Send Sarjt. Gass and G. Shannon to the Salt makers who are on the Sea Coast to the S
column29: W. of us
column30: to enquire after Willard & Wiser who have not yet returned. R. Field
column31: potts & Collins the hunters who Set out on the 28th ulto. returned this evening after dark. they reported that they had been about 15 miles up the river which falls into Meriwethers Bay to the East of us
column32: and had hunted the Country a considerable distance to East
column33: and had proved unsucksesfull haveing killed one Deer and a fiew fowls
column34: bearly as much as Subsisted them. this reminded us of the necessity of takeing time by the forelock
column35: and keep out Several parties while we have yet a little meat beforehand. Capt Lewis gave the Cheif Cania a par of Sattin breechies with which he appeared much pleased. [Lewis
column36: January 4
column37: 1806] Saturday January 4th 1806. Comowooll and the Clatsops who visited us yesterday left us in the evening. These people the Chinnooks and others residing in this neighbourhood and speaking the same language have been very friendly to us; they appear to be a mild inoffensive people but will pilfer if they have an opportuny to do so where they conceive themselves not liable to detection. they are great higlers in trade and if they conceive you anxious to purchase will be a whole day bargaining for a handfull of roots; this I should have thought proceeded from their want of knowledge of the comparitive value of articles of merchandize and the fear of being cheated
column38: did I not find that they invariably refuse the price first offered them and afterwards very frequently accept a smaller quantity of the same article; in order to satisfy myself on this subject I once offered a Chinnook my watch two knives and a considerable quantity of beads for a small inferior sea Otter's skin which I did not much want
column39: he immediately conceived it of great value
column40: and refused to barter except I would double the quantity of beads; the next day with a great deal of importunity on his part I received the skin in exchange for a few strans of the same beads he had refused the day before. I therefore believe this trait in their character proceeds from an avaricious all grasping disposition. in this rispect they differ from all Indians I ever became acquainted with
column41: for their dispositions invariably lead them to give whatever they are possessed off no matter how usefull or valuable
column42: for a bauble which pleases their fancy
column43: without consulting it's usefullness or value. nothing interesting occurred today
column44: or more so
column45: than our wappetoe being all exhausted.

column3: 1806] Saturday 4th January 1806 Comowool and the Clatsops who visited us yesterday left us in the morning. Those people the Chinnook and others resideing in this neighbourhood and Speaking the Same language have been very friendly to us; they appear to be a mild inoffensive people but will pilfer if they have an oppertunity to do So when they Conceive themselves not liable to detection. they are great higlers in trade and if they Conceive you anxious to purchase will be a whole day bargaining for a hand full of roots; this I Should have thought proceeded from their want of Knowledge of the Comparitive value of articles of merchindize and the fear of being Cheated
column4: did I not find that they invariably refuse the price first offered them and afterwards very frequently accept a Smaller quantity of the Same article; in order to Satisfy myself on this point
column5: I once offered a Clatsop man my watch a knife
column6: a Dollar of the Coin of U State and hand full of beeds
column7: for a Small Sea otter Skin
column8: which I did not much want
column9: he immediately Conceived it of great value
column10: and refused to Sell unless I would give as maney more beads; the next day with a great deel of importunity on his part we receved the Skin in exchange for a fiew Strans of the Same beeds he had refused the day before. I therefore beleive this treat in their Charector proceeds from an avericious all grasping dis-position. in this respect they differ from all Indians I ever became acquainted with
column11: for their dispositions invariably lead them to give what ever they are possessed off no matter how usefull or valueable
column12: for a bauble which pleases their fancy
column13: without Consulting its usefullness or value. nothing occured to day
column14: or more So
column15: than our wappato being all exhausted. [Lewis
column16: January 5
column17: 1806] Sunday January 5th 1806. At 5 P.M. Willard and Wiser returned
column18: they had not been lost as we apprehended. they informed us that it was not untill the fifth day after leaving the Fort that they could find a convenient place for making salt; that they had at length established themselves on the coast about 15 Miles S. W. from this
column19: near the lodge of some Killamuck families; that the Indians were very friendly and had given them a considerable quantity of the blubber of a whale which perished on the coast some distance S. E. of them; part of this blubber they brought with them
column20: it was white & not unlike the fat of Poark
column21: tho the texture was more spongey and somewhat coarser. I had a part of it cooked and found it very pallitable and tender
column22: it resembled the beaver or the dog in flavour. it may appear somewhat extraordinary tho it is a fact that the flesh of the beaver and dog possess a very great affinity in point of flavour. These lads also informed us that J. Fields
column23: Bratton and Gibson (the Salt makers) had with their assistance erected a comfortable camp killed an Elk and several deer and secured a good stock of meat; they commenced the making of salt and found that they could obtain from 3 quarts to a gallon a day; they brought with them a specemine of the salt of about a gallon
column24: we found it excellent
column25: fine
column26: strong
column27: & white; this was a great treat to myself and most of the party
column28: having not had any since the 20th ultmo.; I say most of the party
column29: for my friend Capt. Clark declares it to be a mear matter of indifference with him whether he uses it or not; for myself I must confess I felt a considerable inconvenience from the want of it; the want of bread I consider as trivial provided
column30: I get fat meat
column31: for as to the species of meat I am not very particular
column32: the flesh of the dog the horse and the wolf
column33: having from habit become equally formiliar with any other
column34: and I have learned to think that if the chord be sufficiently strong
column35: which binds the soul and boddy together
column36: it dose not so much matter about the materials which compose it. Colter also returned this evening unsuccessfull from the chase
column37: having been absent since the 1st Inst.--Capt. Clark determined this evening to set out early tomorrow with two canoes and 12 men in quest of the whale
column38: or at all events to purchase from the Indians a parcel of the blubber
column39: for this purpose he prepared a small assortment of merchandize to take with him. [Clark
column40: January 5
column41: 1806] Sunday 5th of January 1806 At 5 p.m.Willard and Wiser returned
column42: they had not been lost as we expected. they informd us that it was not untill the 5th day after leaveing the fort
column43: that they Could find a Convenient place for makeing Salt; that they had at length established themselves on the Sea Coast about 15 miles S. W. from this
column44: near the houses of Some Clat Sop & Kil a mox families; that the Indians were very friendly and had given them a considerable quantity of the blubber of the whale which perished on the Coast Some distance S. E. of them
column45: it was white and not unlike the fat of Pork
column46: tho the texture was more Spungey and Somewhat Coarser. we had part of it Cooked and found it very pallitable and tender
column47: it resembles the beaver in flavour. those men also informed us that the Salt makers with their assistance had erected a Comfortable Camp
column48: had killed an Elk and Several Deer and Secured a good Stock of Meat; they Commenced the makeing of Salt and found that they Could make from 3 quarts to a gallon a day; they brought with them a Specimen of the Salt
column49: of about a gallon
column50: we found it excellent white & fine
column51: but not So Strong as the rock Salt or that made in Kentucky or the Western parts of the U
column52: States--this Salt was a great treat to most of the party
column53: haveing not had any Since the 20th ulto. as to my Self I care but little whether I have any with my meat or not; provided the meat fat
column54: haveing from habit become entirely cearless about my diat
column55: and I have learned to think that if the Cord be Sufficiently Strong which binds the Soul and boddy together
column56: it does not So much matter about the materials which Compose it.I determine to Set out early tomorrow with two canoes & 12 men in quest of the whale
column57: or at all events to purchase from the indians a parcel of the blubber
column58: for this purpose I made up a Small assortment of merchindize
column59: and directed the men to hold themselves in readiness &c. [Lewis
column60: January 6
column61: 1806] Monday January 6th 1806. Capt Clark set out after an early breakfast with the party in two canoes as had been concerted the last evening; Charbono and his Indian woman were also of the party; the Indian woman was very impotunate to be permited to go
column62: and was therefore indulged; she observed that she had traveled a long way with us to see the great waters
column63: and that now that monstrous fish was also to be seen
column64: she thought it very hard she could not be permitted to see either (she had never yet been to the Ocean).The Clatsops
column65: Chinnooks
column66: Killamucks &c. are very loquacious and inquisitive; they possess good memories and have repeated to us the names capasities of the vessels &c of many traders and others who have visited the mouth of this river; they are generally low in stature
column67: proportionably small
column68: reather lighter complected and much more illy formed than the Indians of the Missouri and those of our frontier; they are generally cheerfull but never gay. with us their conversation generally turns upon the subjects of trade
column69: smoking
column70: eating or their women; about the latter they speak without reserve in their presents
column71: of their every part
column72: and of the most formiliar connection. they do not hold the virtue of their women in high estimation
column73: and will even prostitute their wives and daughters for a fishinghook or a stran of beads. in common with other savage nations they make their women perform every species of domestic drudgery. but in almost every species of this drudgery the men also participate. their women are also compelled to geather roots
column74: and assist them in taking fish
column75: which articles form much the greatest part of their subsistance; notwithstanding the survile manner in which they treat their women they pay much more rispect to their judgment and oppinions in many rispects than most indian nations; their women are permitted to speak freely before them
column76: and sometimes appear to command with a tone of authority; they generally consult them in their traffic and act in conformity to their opinions. I think it may be established as a general maxim that those nations treat their old people and women with most differrence and rispect where they subsist principally on such articles that these can participate with the men in obtaining them; and that
column77: that part of the community are treated with.least attention
column78: when the act of procuring subsistence devolves intirely on the men in the vigor of life. It appears to me that nature has been much more deficient in her filial tie than in any other of the strong affections of the human heart
column79: and therefore think
column80: our old men equally with our women indebted to civilization for their ease and comfort. Among the Siouxs
column81: Assinniboins and others on the Missouri who subsist by hunting it is a custom when a person of either sex becomes so old and infurm that they are unable to travel on foot from camp to camp as they rome in surch of subsistance
column82: for the children or near relations of such person to leave them without compunction or remose; on those occasions they usually place within their reach a small peace of meat and a platter of water
column83: telling the poor old superannuated wretch for his consolation
column84: that he or she had lived long enough
column85: that it was time they should dye and go to their relations who can afford to take care of them much better than they could. I am informed that this custom prevails even among the Minetares Arwerharmays and Recares when attended by their old people on their hunting excurtions; but in justice to these people I must observe that it appeared to me at their vilages
column86: that they provided tolerably well for their aged persons
column87: and several of their feasts appear to have principally for their object a contribution for their aged and infirm persons.

column1: This day I overhalled our merchandize and dryed it by the fire
column2: found it all damp; we have not been able to keep anything dry for many days together since we arrived in this neighbourhood
column3: the humidity of the air has been so excessively great. our merchandize is reduced to a mear handfull
column4: and our comfort during our return the next year much depends on it
column5: it is therefore almost unnecessary to add that we much regret the reduced state of this fund. [Clark
column6: January 6
column7: 1806] 2 3 4 5 & all Day 6t of January 1805 all last night rained without intermition
column8: & the morning. I sat out with 12 men in 2 Canoes to around thro the bay and up a Creek to an old landing at which place the Indians have a roade across thro Shashes West I landed made the Canoes fast and Set out up the Cree on a road passed thro 3 Stashes to a pond
column9: then up & around th bend along a bad thick way
column10: took an Indian path which took us to a Creek which runs into the Sand bay at which place we found a Canoe which took over 3 men at a time crossed and on the top of a rise Saw Elk prosued & Killed one and encamped at the forks of a Creek the West Eate th Elk all up. a fine Butifull moon Shining night unto _____
column11: Swan Geese
column12: Brand &c. [Clark
column13: January 6
column14: 1806] Monday 6th of January 1806 The last evening Shabono and his Indian woman was very impatient to be permitted to go with me
column15: and was therefore indulged; She observed that She had traveled a long way with us to See the great waters
column16: and that now that monstrous fish was also to be Seen
column17: She thought it verry hard that She Could not be permitted to See either (She had never yet been to the Ocian). after an early brackfast I Set out with two Canoes down the Ne tel R into Meriwether Bay with a view to proced on to the Clatsop town
column18: and hire a guide to conduct me through the Creeks which I had every reason to beleeve Comunicated both with the Bay and a Small river near to which our men were making Salt. Soon after I arrived in the Bay the wind Sprung up from the N. W and blew So hard and raised the waves so high that we were obliged to put into a Small Creek Short of the Village. finding I could not proceed on to the Village in Safty
column19: I deturmined to assend this Creek as high as the Canoes would go; which from its directions must be near the open lands in which I had been on the 10th ulto.
column20: and leave the Canoes and proceed on by land. at the distance of about 3 miles up this Creek I observed Some high open land
column21: at which place a road Set out and had every appearance of a portage
column22: here I landed drew up the Canoes and Set out by land
column23: proceeded on through 3 deep Slashes to a pond about a mile in length and 200 yards wide
column24: kept up this pond leaving it to the right
column25: and passing the head to a Creek which we Could not Cross
column26: this Creek is the one which I rafted on the 8th & 9 ultimo. and at no great distance from where I crossed in Cus ca lars Canoe on the 10th ulto. to which place I expected a find a canoe
column27: we proceeded on and found a Small Canoe at the place I expected
column28: calculated to Carry 3 men
column29: we crossed and from the top of a ridge in the Prarie we Saw a large gange of Elk feeding about 2 miles below on our direction. I divided the party So as to be Certain of an elk
column30: Several Shot were fired only one Elk fell
column31: I had this Elk butchered and carried to a Creak in advance at which place I intended to encamp
column32: two other Elk were badly Shot
column33: but as it was nearly dark we Could not pursue them
column34: we proceeded on to the forks of the Creek which we had just Crossed turning around to the S W. and meeting one of equal Size from the South
column35: the two makeing a little river 70 yards wide which falls into the Ocian near the 3 Clat Sop houses which I visited on the 9th ulto. in the forks of this Creek we found Some drift pine which had been left on the Shore by the tide of which we made fires. the evening a butifull Clear moon Shiney night
column36: and the 1st fair night which we have had for 2 months [Lewis
column37: January 7
column38: 1806] Monday January 7th 1806. Last evening Drewyer visited his traps and caught a beaver and an otter; the beaver was large and fat we have therefore fared sumptuously today; this we consider a great prize for another reason
column39: it being a full grown beaver was well supplyed with the materials for making bate with which to catch others. this bate when properly prepared will intice the beaver to visit it as far as he can smell it
column40: and this I think may be safely stated at a mile
column41: their sense of smelling being very accute. To prepare beaver bate
column42: the castor or bark stone is taken as the base
column43: this is gently pressed out of the bladderlike bag which contains it
column44: into a phiol of 4 ounces with a wide mouth; if you have them you will put from four to six stone in a phiol of that capacity
column45: to this you will add half a nutmeg
column46: a douzen or 15 grains of cloves and thirty grains of cinimon finely pulverized
column47: stir them well together and then add as much ardent sperits to the composition as will reduce it the consistency mustard prepared for the table; when thus prepared it resembles mustard precisely to all appearance. when you cannot procure a phiol a bottle made of horn or a tight earthen vessel will answer
column48: in all cases it must be excluded from the air or it will soon loose it's virtue; it is fit for uce immediately it is prepared but becomes much stronger and better in about four or five days and will keep for months provided it be perfectly secluded from the air. when cloves are not to be had use double the quantity of Allspice
column49: and when no spice can be obtained use the bark of the root of sausafras; when sperits cannot be had use oil stone of the beaver adding mearly a sufficient quantity to moisten the other materials
column50: or reduce it to a stif past. it appears to me that the principal uce of the spices is only to give a variety to the scent of the bark stone and if so the mace vineller and other sweetsmelling spices might be employed with equal advantage. The male beaver has six stones
column51: two which contain a substance much like finely pulvarized bark of a pale yellow colour and not unlike tanner's ooz in smell
column52: these are called the bark stones or castors; two others
column53: which like the bark stone resemble small bladders
column54: contain a pure oil of a strong rank disagreeable smell
column55: and not unlike train oil
column56: these are called the oil stones; and 2 others of generation. the Barkstones are about two inches in length
column57: the others somewhat smaller all are of a long oval form; and lye in a bunch together between the skin and the root of the tail
column58: beneath or behind the fundament with which they are closely connected and seem to communicate. the pride of the female lyes on the inner side much like those of the hog. they have no further parts of generation that I can perceive and therefore beleive that like the birds they copulate with the extremity of the gut. The female have from two to four young ones at a birth and bring fourth once a year only
column59: which usually happens about the latter end of may and begining of June. at this stage she is said to drive the male from the lodge
column60: who would otherwise destroy the young.--dryed our lodge and had it put away under shelter; this is the first day during which we have had no rain since we arrived at this place. nothing extraordinary happened today. [Clark
column61: January 7
column62: 1806] Jany 7th Tuesday 1806 Set out at Day light
column63: porceded up the Creek about 2 mile and crossed on a tree trunk the Salt makers have fallen across
column64: then proceeded on to the Ocean 3/4 mile & proceded up 3 miles to the mouth of Colimex River about 80 or 100 yds wide verry rapid & Cuts its banks
column65: here we found an old Village of 3 houses
column66: one only inhabited by one familey
column67: I gave the man a fish hook to put the party across
column68: on the bank found a Skeet fish which had been lef by the tide proceded on 2 miles on the bank opposit a kind of bay the river Cross to the Sea Cost to 2 Inds Indians Lodges at which place I found our Salt makers near the foot of a mountain which form the Shore. Brackfast and hirired an Indian to pilot me to the Ca le mix nation where the whale is for which I gave a file
column69: we proceded on the Stone under a high hill on our right bluff. Soft Stone Sees verry high
column70: Several parts of this hill recently Sliped in
column71: about 3/4 of a mile abov the Houses Saw a Canoe in which the Dead was buried at 21/2 miles assended a Steep mountain
column72: as Steep at it is possible places for 1500 feet we hauled our Selves up by the assistence of the bushes if one had Given way we must have fallen a great distant the Steepest worst & highest mountain I ever assended I think it at least 1500 feet highr than the Sea imidiately under on the riht. we met 14 Indians loaded with blubber proceded on thro an unusual bad way falling timber bendig under logs &c. and encamped on a Creek which runs to my left find Day and night
column73: the timber Spruc White Cedar & &.

column3: 1806] Tuesday 7th of January 1806 Some frost this morning. It may appear Somewhat incrediable
column4: but So it is that the Elk which was killed last evening was eaten except about 8 pounds
column5: which I directed to be taken along with the Skin
column6: I proceded up the South fork of the Creek about 2 miles and crossed on a pine tree which had been fallen by the Saltmakers on their first going out
column7: on this tree we crossed the deepest of the water and waded on the opposit Side for 30 yards
column8: from thence to the ocian 3/4 of a mile through a Continuation of open ridgey Prarie
column9: here the Coast is Sandy
column10: we proceeded on the Sandy beech nearly South for 3 miles to the mouth of butifull river with bold and rapid Current of 85 yards wide and 3 feet deep in the Shallowest place
column11: a Short distance up this river on the N E Side is the remains of an old village of Clatsops. I entered a house where I found a Man 2 Womn & 3 Children
column12: they appeared retchedly pore & dirty
column13: I hired the man to Set us across the River which I call after the Nation Clat Sop river for which I gave 2 fishing hooks--at this place the Creek over which I crossed on a tree passes within 100 yards of the Clat Sop river over which the nativs have a portage which affords them an easy Communication with the villages near point adams
column14: and at the mouth of the Creek
column15: on which we lay last night. in walking on the Sand after crossing the river I Saw a Singular Species of fish which I had never before Seen one of the men Call this fish a Skaite
column16: it is properly a Thornback. I proceeded on about 2 miles to near the base of high Mountain where I found our Salt makers
column17: and with them Sergt. Gass
column18: Geo. Shannon was out in the woods assisting Jo Field and gibson to kill Some meat
column19: the Salt makers had made a neet Close Camp
column20: Convenient to wood Salt water and the fresh water of the Clat Sop river which at this place was within 100 paces of the Ocian they wer also Situated near 4 houses of Clatsops & Killamox
column21: who they informed me had been verry kind and attentive to them. I hired a young Indian to pilot me to the whale for which Service I gave him a file in hand and promised Several other Small articles on my return
column22: left Sergt. Gass and one man of my party Werner to make Salt & permited Bratten to accompany me
column23: we proceeded on the round Slipery Stones under a high hill which projected into the ocian about 4 miles further than the direction of the Coast. after walking for 21/2 miles on the Stones my guide made a Sudin halt
column24: pointed to the top of the mountain and uttered the word Pe Shack which means bad
column25: and made Signs that we could not proceed any further on the rocks
column26: but must pass over that mountain
column27: I hesitated a moment & view this emence mountain the top of which was obscured in the clouds
column28: and the assent appeard. to be almost perpindecular; as the Small Indian parth allong which they had brought emence loads but a fiew hours before
column29: led up this mountain and appeared to assend in a Sideling direction
column30: I thought more than probable that the assent might be torerably easy and therefore proceeded on
column31: I soon found that the ____ become much worst as I assended
column32: and at one place we were obliged to Support and draw our Selves up by the bushes & roots for near 100 feet
column33: and after about 2 hours labour and fatigue we reached the top of this high mountain
column34: from the top of which I looked down with estonishment to behold the hight which we had assended
column35: which appeared to be 10 or 12 hundred feet up a mountain which appeared to be almost perpindicular
column36: here we met 14 Indians men and women loaded with the oil & Blubber of the whale. In the face of this tremendeous precipic imediately below us
column37: there is a Strater of white earth (which my guide informed me) the neighbouring indians use to paint themselves
column38: and which appears to me to resemble the earth of which the French Porcelain is made; I am confident that this earth Contains argill
column39: but whether it also Contains Silex or magnesia
column40: or either of those earths in a proper perpotion I am unable to deturmine. we left the top of the precipice and proceeded on a bad road and encamped on a Small run passin g to the left. all much fatiagued [Lewis
column41: January 8
column42: 1806] Tuesday January 8th 1806. Our meat is begining to become scarse; sent Drewyer and Collins to hunt this morning. the guard duty being hard on the men who now remain in the fort I have for their relief since the departure of Capt. Clark made the Cooks mount guard. Sergt. Gass and Shannon have not yet returned
column43: nor can I immajen what is the cause of their detention. In consequence of the clouds this evening I lost my P.M. observation for Equal Altitudes
column44: and from the same cause have not been able to take a single observation since we have been at this place. nothing extraordinary happened today.The Clatsops Chinnooks and others inhabiting the coast and country in this neighbourhood
column45: are excessively fond of smoking tobacco. in the act of smoking they appear to swallow it as they dran it from the pipe
column46: and for many draughts together you will not perceive the smoke which they take from the pipe; in the same manner also they inhale it in their lungs untill they become surcharged with this vapour when they puff it out to a great distance through their nostils and mouth; I have no doubt the smoke of the tobacco in this manner becomes much more intoxicating and that they do possess themselves of all it's virtues in their fullest extent; they freequently give us sounding proofs of it's creating a dismorallity of order in the abdomen
column47: nor are those light matters thought indelicate in either sex
column48: but all take the liberty of obeying the dictates of nature without reserve. these people do not appear to know the uce of sperituous liquors
column49: they never having once asked us for it; I presume therefore that the traders who visit them have never indulged them with the uce of it; from what ever cause this may proceede
column50: it is a very fortunate occurrence
column51: as well for the natives themselves
column52: as for the quiet and safety of thos whites who visit them. [Clark
column53: January 8
column54: 1806] Jany 8 Wedned Set out at Day a fine morning wind hard from S. E at 11/2 miles arived at a Open where I had a view of the Seas Coast for a long Distance rocks in every direction. Struck a branch and come down to the Sea at which place an old village between 2 Creeks of the Colemix Nation which inhabits this Coast
column55: grave yard deposed of in Canoes in which the bodies are laid in boxes in the Canoe
column56: Paddles &c thos poople must use thos Canoes in the higher Seas of which then ever I Saw on a Cost ruding Countrey Crossed 3 points rocks great Distanc in the Sea
column57: hill Sides Sliping from emins ravins which appears to _____ proceeded on to the mouth of a Creek about 80 yards wide at which Place I saw 5 Lodges of Indian of the Ca la mix nation
column58: boiling whale in a trough of about 20 gallons with hot Stones
column59: and the oyle they put into a Canoe I proceded on a Short distance to the whales which was nothing more than the Sceleton
column60: of 105 feet long
column61: we took out a few bones and returned to the Cabins at the mouth of the Creek
column62: and attempted to trade with thos people who I found Close and Capricious
column63: would not trade the Smallest piece except they thought they got an advantage of the bargain
column64: their disposition is averitious
column65: & independant in trade
column66: they offered to trade for Elk of which we had not I purchased some oile and about 120 w of Blubber after rendered
column67: finding they would not trade I Deturmined to return home with what we have The Houses of these people appear temporary a ridge pole on 2 forks Supported a Certain number of Split boards of the red Cedar & pine
column68: Set on the end the gable ends of the Same materials and Calculated for 2 families first
column69: The Dress and appearenc of the nativs as also the language is procisely that of the Clopsots & Chinnooks
column70: those people Save their oile in bladder Guts &c.Their food is principally fish that is thrown on the Shores by the Seas & left by the tide
column71: This Cost is rockey
column72: the mountains high & rugged
column73: They inform me that their nation lives in 5 villages to the S E of this place at the mouths of Creek in which they catch Samn. in the Season
column74: I got of those people a few roots Some Sturgeon whale-____ &. They Call a whale E cu-la a Creek Shu man
column75: they have Some fiew Sea ortter for which they ask Such prices I could not purchase any of them

column1: Th party much fatigued in crossing 1 mountain & 4 high Points Steep & Slipery
column2: also Stony Beach Slippery and tiresom The high tide obliged me to delay untill late before the tide put out
column3: I Shot a raven & a gul with my Small riffle which Suppised these people a little They are fond of blue & white large beed only
column4: files & fish Hooks which are large- after Diner we Set out Crossed the Creek in a Small Canoe The tide out and Encamped on the opposit Side
column5: I was asked for ferrage and paid a pin
column6: one hut on the Side in which I Camped & Village a Short distance above which I did not See last night
column7: all the men came over & Smoked with me
column8: about bed time I herd a hollowing on the opposit Side of the river which allarnied all the Indian men about me
column9: they run across the Creek
column10: I Suspected perhaps Some of my party was over after the Squars
column11: by exemening found that McNeal was not in Camp
column12: my guide who Staid with me told me Some body throat was Cut. I emediately Sent Serjt Pryor & 2 men across for McNeal
column13: they Soon returned haveing met the person I was anxious to find out the Cause of the allarm
column14: McNeal Said that a man envited him to go across and get Some fish
column15: locked arms of which he Contd to hold he took him into a lodge and the woman gave him a Small piec the man then invited him to another
column16: the woman of the lodge puled his blanket
column17: & Sent out a Squar to hollow across
column18: to inform of Something which aid. McNeal I Sent over Sergt. Pryor to Know the Cause of the allarm which he was informed that a Plot was laid to kill McNeal for his Blanket & Clothes by this Indian who was from another Villg at Some distance
column19: and that She had attempted to Stop McNeal & findeing She Could not that She then allarmed the men
column20: Several of the mans Band was with me who imedeately Cleared out
column21: 2 men Came over & Slept at my feet. I kept a guard & Sentinel all night a fair night wind blew from S. E. during the evening I acquired all the information possiable respecting the Coast to the S. E. got the name of many nations & the Nos. of their houses
column22: a map of the Coast in their way. I am very pore & weak for want of Sufficient food and fear much that I shall require more assistance to get back than I had to get to this place. a deturmined purcistance will as it has done carry me through [Clark
column23: January 8
column24: 1806] Wednesday 8th January 1805 The last night proved fair and Cold wind hard from the S. E. we Set out early and proceeded to the top of the mountain next to the which is much the highest part and that part faceing the Sea is open
column25: from this point I beheld the grandest and most pleasing prospects which my eyes ever surveyed
column26: in my frount a boundless Ocean; to the N. and N. E. the coast as as far as my sight Could be extended
column27: the Seas rageing with emence wave and brakeing with great force from the rocks of Cape Disapointment as far as I could See to the N. W. The Clatsops Chinnooks and other villagers on each Side of the Columbia river and in the Praries below me
column28: the meanderings of 3 handsom Streams heading in Small lakes at the foot the high Country; The Columbia River for a Some distance up
column29: with its Bays and Small rivers and on the other Side I have a view of the Coast for an emence distance to the S. E. by S. the nitches and points of high land which forms this Corse for a long ways aded to the inoumerable rocks of emence Sise out at a great distance from the Shore and against which the Seas brak with great force gives this Coast a most romantic appearance. from this point of View my guide pointed to a village at the mouth of a Small river near which place he Said the whale was
column30: he also pointed to 4 other places where the princpal Villages of the Kil la mox were Situated
column31: I could plainly See the houses of 2 of those Villeges & the Smoke of a 3rd which was two far of for me to disern with my naked eye--after taking the Courses and computed the Distances in my own mind
column32: I proceeded on down a Steep decent to a Single house the remains of an old Kil a mox Town in a nitch imediately on the Sea Coast
column33: at which place great no. of eregular rocks are out and the waves comes in with great force. Near this old Town I observed large Canoes of the neetest kind on the ground Some of which appeared nearly decayed others quit Sound
column34: I examoned those Canoes and found they were the repository of the dead--This Custom of Secureing the Dead differs a little from the Chinnooks. the Kil a mox Secure the dead bodies in an oblong box of Plank
column35: which is placed in an open Canoe resting on the ground
column36: in which is put a paddle and Sundery other articles the property of the disceased. The Coast in the neighbourhood of this old village is slipping from the Sides of the high hills
column37: in emence masses; fifty or a hundred acres at a time give way and a great proportion of an instant precipitated into the Ocean. those hills and mountains are principally composed of a yellow Clay; their Slipping off or Spliting assunder at this time is no doubt Caused by the incessant rains which has fallen within the last two months. the mountans Covered with a verry heavy Croth of pine & furr
column38: also the white Cedar or arbor vita and a Small proportion of the black alder
column39: this alder grows to the hight of Sixty or Seventy feet and from 2 to 3 feet in diamiter. Some Species of pine on the top of the Point of View rise to the emmence hight of 210 feet and from 8 to 12 feet in diameter
column40: and are perfectly Sound and Solid. Wind hard from the S. E and See looked ____ in the after part of the Day breaking with great force against the Scattering rocks at Some distance from Shore
column41: and the ruged rockey points under which we wer obleged to pass and if we had unfortunately made one false Stet we Should eneviateably have fallen into the Sea and dashed against the rocks in an instant
column42: fortunately we passed over 3 of those dismal points and arived on a butifull Sand Shore on which we Continued for 2 miles
column43: Crossed a Creek 80 yards near 5 Cabins
column44: and proceeded to the place the whale had perished
column45: found only the Skelleton of this monster on the Sand between 2 of the villages of the Kil a mox nation; the Whale was already pillaged of every valuable part by the Kil a mox Inds. in the vecinity of whose village's it lay on the Strand where the waves and tide had driven up & left it. this Skeleton measured 105 feet. I returned to the village of 5 Cabins on the Creek which I shall call E co-la or whale Creek
column46: found the nativs busily engaged boiling the blubber
column47: which they performed in a large Squar wooden trought by means of hot Stones; the oil when extracted was Secured in bladders and the Guts of the whale; the blubber from which the oil was only partially extracted by this process
column48: was laid by in their Cabins in large flickes for use; those flickes they usially expose to the fire on a wooden Spit untill it is prutty well wormed through and then eate it either alone or with roots of the rush
column49: Shaw na tdk we or diped in the oil. The Kil a mox although they possessed large quantities of this blubber and oil were so prenurious that they disposed of it with great reluctiance and in Small quantities only; insomuch that my utmost exertion aided by the party with the Small Stock of merchindize I had taken with me were not able to precure more blubber than about 300 wt. and a fiew gallons of oil; Small as this Stock is I prise it highly; and thank providence for directing the whale to us; and think him much more kind to us than he was to jonah
column50: having Sent this monster to be Swallowed by us in Sted of Swallowing of us as jonah's did. I recrossed E co la Creek and Encamped on the bank at which place we observed an ebundance of fine wood the Indian men followed me for the purpose of Smokeing. I enquired of those people as well as I could by Signs the Situation
column51: mode of liveing & Strength of their nation They informed me that the bulk of their nation lived in 3 large villages Still further along the Sea coast to the S
column52: S
column53: W. at the enterence Of 3 Creek which fell into a bay
column54: and that other houses were Scattered about on the Coast
column55: Bay and on a Small river which fell into the Bay in which they Cought Salmon
column56: and from this Creek (which I call Kil a mox River) they crossed over to the Wappato I. on the Shock-ah-lil com (which is the Indian name for the Columbia river) and purchased Wappato &c. that the nation was once verry large and that they had a great maney houses
column57: In Salmon Season they Cought great numbers of that fish in the Small Creeks
column58: when the Salmon was Scerce they found Sturgion and a variety of other fish thrown up by the waves and left by the tide which was verry fine
column59: Elk was plenty in the mountains
column60: but they Could not Kill maney of them with their arrows. The Kil d mox in their habits Customs manners dress & language differ but little from the Clatsops
column61: Chinnooks and others in this neighbourhood are of the Same form of those of the Clatsops with a Dore at each end & two fire places i
column62: e the house is double as long as wide and divided into 2 equal parts with a post in the middle Supporting the ridge pole
column63: and in the middle of each of those divisions they make their fires
column64: dotes Small & houses Sunk 5 feet [Lewis
column65: January 9
column66: 1806] Friday January 9th 1806. Our men are now very much engaged in dressing Elk and Deer skins for mockersons and cloathing. the deer are extreemly scarce in this neighbourhood
column67: some are to be found near the praries and open grounds along the coast. this evening we heard seven guns in quick succession after each other
column68: they appeared to be on the Creek to the South of us and several miles distant; I expect that the hunters Drewyer and Collins have fallen in with a gang of Elk. some marrow bones and a little fresh meat would be exceptable; I have been living for two days past on poor dryed Elk
column69: or jurk as the hunters term it.

column1: The Clatsops Chinnooks &c. bury their dead in their canoes. for this purpose four pieces of split timber are set erect on end
column2: and sunk a few feet in the grown
column3: each brace having their flat sides opposite to each other and sufficiently far assunder to admit the width of the canoes in which the dead are to be deposited; through each of these perpendicular posts
column4: at the hight of six feet a mortice is cut
column5: through which two bars of wood are incerted; on these cross bars a small canoe is placed in which the body is laid after being carefully roled in a robe of some dressed skins; a paddle is also deposited with them; a larger canoe is now reversed
column6: overlaying and imbracing the small one
column7: and resting with it's gunwals on the cross bars; one or more large mats of rushes or flags are then roled around the canoes and the whole securely lashed with a long cord
column8: usually made of the bark of the Arbor vita or white cedar. on the cross bars which support the canoes is frequently hung or laid various articles of cloathing culinary eutensels &c. I cannot understand them sufficiently to make any enquiries relitive to their religeous opinions
column9: but presume from their depositing various articles with their dead
column10: that they believe in a state of future existence.The persons who usually visit the entrance of this river for the purpose of traffic or hunting I believe are either English or Americans; the Indians inform us that they speak the same language with ourselves
column11: and give us proofs of their varacity by repeating many words of English
column12: as musquit
column13: powder
column14: shot
column15: nife
column16: file
column17: damned rascal
column18: sun of a bitch &c. whether these traders are from Nootka sound
column19: from some other late establishment on this coast
column20: or immediately from the U States or Great Brittain
column21: I am at a loss to determine
column22: nor can the Indians inform us. the Indians whom I have asked in what direction the traders go when they depart from hence
column23: or arrive here
column24: always point to the S. W. from which it is presumeable that Nootka cannot be their destination; and as from Indian information a majority of these traders annually visit them about the beginning of April and remain with them six or seven Months
column25: they cannot come immediately from Great Britain or the U States
column26: the distance being too great for them to go and return in the ballance of the year. from this circumstance I am sometimes induced to believe that there is some other establishment on the coast of America south West of this place of which little is but yet known to the world
column27: or it may be perhaps on some Island in the pacific ocean between the Continents of Asia and America to the South West of us. This traffic on the part of the whites consists in vending
column28: guns
column29: (principally old british or American musquits) powder
column30: balls and Shot
column31: Copper and brass kettles
column32: brass teakettles and coffee pots
column33: blankets from two to three point
column34: scarlet and blue Cloth (coarse)
column35: plates and strips of sheet copper and brass
column36: large brass wire
column37: knives
column38: beads and tobacco with fishinghooks buttons and some other small articles; also a considerable quantity of Sailor's cloaths
column39: as hats coats
column40: trowsers and shirts. for these they receive in return from the natives
column41: dressed and undressed Elkskins
column42: skins of the sea Otter
column43: common Otter
column44: beaver
column45: common fox
column46: spuck
column47: and tiger cat; also dryed and pounded sammon in baskets
column48: and a kind of buisquit
column49: which the natives make of roots called by them shappelell. The natives are extravegantly fond of the most common cheap blue and white beads
column50: of moderate size
column51: or such that from 50 to 70 will weigh one penneyweight. the blue is usually pefered to the white; these beads constitute the principal circulating medium with all the indian tribes on this river; for these beads they will dispose any article they possess.--the beads are strung on strans of a fathom in length and in that manner sold by the bredth or yard.- [Clark
column52: January 9
column53: 1806] January 9th Thursday 1806 a fine morning wind N E Set out at day lighte every man Some meat of the whale and a little oile proceded on the track we Came out to a house at a branch where we halted 1/2 an hour to rest this house is at at place an old village has formerly been
column54: on the Coast at the Comencment ____ 27 foot wide 35 feet long Sunk in the ground 5 feet 2 Dotes & 2 fire places dotes 29 Ins. high & 141/4 wide handsom Steps to decend down a post in the middle Coverede with boards Split thin an 2 feet wide
column55: old grave in Canoes of 3 feet 8 Inches wide & 5 feet long neetly made high at bow proceded on to the top of the hill Passing 3 bad points rockey &. from the Point Clarks Point of view Cape Disapt. bears S. 12° E passing a Great point at 15 miles one at 40 miles rocks out to the 1st large point from the Creek 4 points
column56: between the 1st large Point and 2d a point of many large rocks
column57: Day Clouded up
column58: I can See a point Bearing N 5° East along way just in Sight. from Clarks View Point to Cape Disapointment is N 20° W. To point adams &the open Slope point is North and a Sharp point
column59: met a party of Chinnooks going to get whale blubber to eate & oile each of which they eate together
column60: we also over took Several parties of the Clot Sops loaded with imence laods of the blubber and oile maney of those loads I with difficuelty raised
column61: Estonishing what custom will do. at 2 oClock we arrived at the Camp of our Salt makers verry much fatigued
column62: more So than I ever was before
column63: the Indians all proceeded on
column64: I concluded to Stay all night
column65: as the party was much fatigued
column66: and Send out 2 men which I had left here to hunt Ducks up the little river
column67: Jo. Fields had killed an Elk and brought in a quarter on which we Dined he also had killed & brought in a Deer. The Indians with the oile & bluber tole me they had to purchase of the Ca-le nixx and would Come to the fort & Sell to us in 3 Days time
column68: this I incouraged
column69: as I expect to purchase at the fort as cheep as at the village at which I was
column70: day proved fine. rained the greater part of the night I went into an Indian Lodge they were pore Durty and the house full of flees. he offered me roots which they geather on the Sea Cost a kind of rush
column71: of which they offered me to eate
column72: [Clark
column73: January 9
column74: 1806] Thursday 9th of January 1806 a fine morning wind from the N. E. last night about 10 oClock while Smokeing with the nativ's I was alarmed by a loud Srile voice from the Cabins on the opposite Side
column75: the Indians all run immediately across to the village
column76: my guide who Continued with me made Signs that Some one's throat was Cut
column77: by enquiry I found that one man McNeal was absent
column78: I imediately Sent off Sergt. N. Pryor & 4 men in quest of McNeal who they met comeing across the Creak in great hast
column79: and informed me that the people were alarmed on the opposit Side at Something but what he could not tell
column80: a man had verry friendly envited him to go and eate in his lodge
column81: that the Indian had locked armes with him and went to a lodge in which a woman gave him Some blubber
column82: that the man envited him to another lodge to get Something better
column83: and the woman held him by the blanket which he had around him another ran out and hollow'd and his pretended friend disapeared--I emediately ordered every man to hold themselves in a State of rediness and Sent Sergt. Pryor & 4 men to know the cause of the alarm which was found to be a premeditated plan of the pretended friend of McNeal to assanate for his Blanket and what fiew articles he had about him
column84: which was found out by a Chin nook woman who allarmed the men of the village who were with me in time to prevent the horred act. this man was of another band at Some distance and ran off as Soon as he was discovered. we have now to look back and Shudder at the dreadfull road on which we have to return of 45 miles S E of Point adams & 35 miles from Fort Clatsop. I had the blubber & oil divided among the party and Set out about Sunrise and returned by the Same rout we had went out
column85: met Several parties of men & womin of the Chinnook and Clatsops nations
column86: on their way to trade with the Kil a mox for blubber and oil; on the Steep decent of the Mountain I overtook five men and Six womin with emence loads of the Oil and blubber of the Whale
column87: those Indians had passed by Some rout by which we missed them as we went out yesterday; one of the women in the act of getting down a Steep part of the mountain her load by Some means had Sliped off her back
column88: and She was holding the load by a Strap which was fastened to the mat bag in which it was in
column89: in one hand and holding a bush by the other
column90: as I was in front of my party
column91: I endeavored to relieve this woman by takeing her load untill She Could get to a better place a little below
column92: & to my estonishment found the load as much as I Could lift and must exceed 100 wt. the husband of this woman who was below Soon came to her releif
column93: those people proceeded on with us to the Salt works
column94: at which place we arrived late in the evening
column96: and 3 of the Party J. Field Gibson & Shannon out hunting. as I was excessively fatigued and my party appeared verry much so
column97: I deturmined to Stay untill the morning and rest our Selves a little. The Clatsops proceeded on with their lodes--The Clatsops
column98: Chin nooks Kil a mox &c. are verry loquacious and inquisitive; they possess good memories and have repeeted to us the names capasities of the Vessels &c of maney traders and others who have visited the mouth of this river; they are generally low in Statue
column100: reather lighter complected and much more illy formed than the Indians of the Missouri and those of our fronteers; they are generally Chearfull but never gay. with us their Conversation generally turns upon the subject of trade
column102: eating or their womin; about the latter
column103: they Speak without reserve in their presence
column105: and of the most farmiliar Connection. they do not hold the virtue of their womin in high estimation
column106: and will even prostitute their wives and Daughters for a fishing hook or a Stran of beeds. in Common with other Savage nations they make their womin perform every Species of domestic drugery; but in almost every Species of this drugery the men also participate. their woman are compelled to gather roots
column107: and assist them in takeing fish; which articles form much the greater part of their Subsistance; notwithstanding the Survile manner in which they treat their womin they pay much more respect to their judgement and oppinion in maney respects than most indian nations; their womin are permited to Speak freely before them
column108: and Sometimes appear to command with a tone of authority; they generally consult them in their traffic and act conformably to their opinions.

column1: I think it may be established as a general maxim that those nations treat their old people and women with most defference and respect where they Subsist principally on Such articles that these can participate with the men in obtaining them; and that
column2: that part of the Community are treated with least attention
column3: when the act of precureing subsistance devolves intirely on the men in the vigor of life. It appears to me that nature has been much more deficient in her filial ties than in any others of the Strong effections of the humane heart
column4: and therefore think our old men equally with our woman indebted to Sivilization for their ease and Comfort. I am told among the Sioux's
column5: Assinniboins and others on the Missouri who Subsist by hunting it is a Custom when a person of either Sex becoms So old and infirm that they are unable to travel on foot
column6: from Camp to Camp as they rove in serch of Subsistance
column7: for the Children or near relations of Such person to leave them without Compunction or remorse; on those occasions they usially place within their reach a Small piece of meat and a platter of water
column8: telling the poor old Superannuated retch for their Consolation
column9: that he or She had lived long enough
column10: and that it was time they Should die and go to their relations who Can afford to take Care of them
column11: much better than they Could. I am informed that the Me ne tar es Ar war har mays and Ricares when attended by their old people on their hunting expedition prosued the Same Custom; but injustice to those people I must observe that it appeared to me at their villages
column12: that they provided tolerably well for their aged persons
column13: and Several of their feasts appear to have principally for their object a contribution for their aged and infirm persons. In one of the Mandan villages I Saw an old man to whome I gave a knife and enquired his age
column14: he Said he had Seen more than 100 winters
column15: and that he Should Soon go down the river to their old village--he requested I would give him Something to prevent the pain in his back his grand Son a Young man rebuked the old man and Said it was not worth while
column16: that it was time for the old man to die. the old man occupied one Side of the fire and was furnished with plenty of Covouring and food
column17: and every attention appeared to be paid him &c. Jo. Field in my absence had killed an Elk and a Deer
column18: brought in the Deer and half of the Elk on a part of which we Suped
column19: Some rain a little after dark. I visited a house near the Salt boilers found it inhabited by 2 families
column20: they were pore dirty and their house Sworming with flees.- [Lewis
column21: January 10
column22: 1806] Saturday January 10th 1806. About 10 A.M. I was visited by Tia Shah-har-war-cap and eleven of his nation in one large canoe; these are the Cuth'-lah-mah nation who reside first above us on the South side of the Columbia river; this is the first time that I have seen the Chief
column23: he was hunting when we past his vilage on our way to this place. I gave him a medal of the smallest size; he presented me with some indian tobacco and a basquit of wappetoe
column24: in return for which I gave him some thread for making a skiming net and a small piece of tobacco. these people speak the same language with the Chinnooks and Catsops whom they also resemble in their dress customs manners &c. they brought some dryed salmon
column25: wappetoe
column26: dogs
column27: and mats made of rushes and flags
column28: to barter; their dogs and a part of their wappetoe they disposed off
column29: an remained all night near the fort. This morning Drewyer and Collins returned having killed two Elk only
column30: and one of those had died in their view over a small lake which they had not the means of passing it being late in the evening and has of course spoiled
column31: as it laid with the entrals in it all night; as the tide was going out we could not send for the elk today
column32: therefore ordered a party to go for it early in the morning and George and Collins to continue their hunt; meat has now become scarce with us.Capt Clark returned at to P.M. this evening with the majority of the party who accompanyed him; having left some men to assist the saltmakers to bring in the meat of two Elk which they had killed
column33: and sent 2 others through by land to hunt. Capt. Clark found the whale on the Coast about 45 Miles S. E. of Point Adams
column34: and about 35 Miles from Fort Clatsop by the rout he took; The whale was already pillaged of every valuable part by the Killamucks
column35: in the vicinity of one of whose villages it lay on the strand where the waves and tide had driven up and left it. this skelleton measured one hundred and five feet. Capt. C. found the natives busily engaged in boiling the blubber
column36: which they performed in a large wooden trought by means of hot stones; the oil when extracted was secured in bladders and the guts of the whale; the blubber
column37: from which the oil was only partially extracted by this process
column38: was laid by in their lodges in large fliches for uce; this they usually expose to the fire on a wooden spit untill it is pretty well warmed through and then eat it either alone or with the roots of the rush
column39: squawmash
column40: fern wappetoe &c. The natives although they possessed large quantities of this blubber and oil were so penurious that they disposed of it with great reluctance and in small quantities only; insomuch that the utmost exertions of Capt. C. and the whole party aided by the little stock of merchandize he had taken with him and some small articles which the men had
column41: were not able to procure more blubber than about 300 lb. and a few gallons of the oil; this they have brought with them
column42: and small as the store is
column43: we prize it highly
column44: and thank providence for directing the whale to us
column45: and think him much more kind to us than he was jonah
column46: having sent this monster to be swallowed by us in stead of swallowing of us as jona's did. Capt. C. found the road along the coast extreemly difficult of axcess
column47: lying over some high rough and stoney hills
column48: one of which he discribes as being much higher than the others
column49: having it's base washed by the Ocean over which it rares it's towering summit perpendicularly to the hight of 1500 feet; from this summit Capt. C. informed me that there was a delightfull and most extensive view of the Ocean
column50: the coast and adjacent country; this Mout. I have taken the liberty of naming Clark's Mountain and point of view; it is situated about 30 M. S. E. of Point Adams and projects about 21/2 miles into the Ocean; Killamucks river falls in a little to the N. W. of this mountain; in the face of this tremendious precepice there is a stra of white earth (see specimen No. ____) which the neighbouring Indians use to paint themselves
column51: and which appears to me to resemble the earth of which the French Porcelain is made; I am confident this earth contains Argill
column52: but wether it also contains Silex or magnesia
column53: or either of those earths in a proper proportion I am unable to determine.--Shannon and Gass were found with the Salt makers and ordered to return McNeal was near being assassinated by a Killamuck Indian
column54: but fortunately escaped in consequence of a Chinnook woman giving information to Capt. C.
column55: the party and Indians with them before the villain had prepaired himself to execute his purposes. The party returned excessively fortiegued and tired of their jaunt. Killamucks river is 85 yards wide
column56: rappid and 3 feet deep in the shallowest part. The Killamucks in their habits customs manners dress and language differ but little from the Clatsops & Chinnooks. they place their dead in canoes resting on the ground uncovered
column57: having previously secured the dead bodies in an oblong box of plank.

column1: The coast in the neighbourhood of Clarks Mountain is sliping off & falling into the Ocean in immence masses; fifty or a hundred Acres at a time give way and a great proportion in an instant precipitated into the Ocean. these hills and mountains are principally composed of a yellow clay; there sliping off or spliting assunder at this time is no doubt caused by the incessant rains which have fallen within the last two months. the country in general as about Fort Clatsop is covered with a very heavy growth of several species of pine & furr
column2: also the arbor vita or white cedar and a small proportion of the black Alder which last sometimes grows to the hight of sixty or seventy feet
column3: and from two to four feet in diameter. some species of the pine rise to the immence hight of 210 feet and are from 7 to 12 feet in diameter
column4: and are perfectly sound and solid. [Clark
column5: January 10
column6: 1806] Jany 10 Friday 1806 I left Sergt. Gass here and Set out at Sun rise
column7: Crossed the little river which I waded 85 yards wide & 3 feet Deep Swift
column8: at which place I Saw Several Indians one of which had 2 butifull Sea orter Skins on as a roabe
column9: here the Creek which I crossed at a tree and on which I camped the 6th inst. came within 200 yds of the river & they Inds. make a portage here
column10: Continued on a place 3 miles Crossed this Creek in a Small Canoe. here I expected to find Shannon and gibson with meet to furnish the Salt makers
column11: but did not
